title: Luxurious stay!
text:
This is a lovely place with a very elegant looking room. We stayed in a Madison suite. The room felt kind of eerie, actually. However, I loved all the details in the room. They looked classy and well maintained. The sheets and toiletries were luxurious. The bed was so comfortable. It made me go into a deep sleep that not even an earthquake could wake me up.  Our butlers on different days were so professional and very attentive. They made sure we were comfortable and we had everything we needed.  The bellman and doorman were always friendly and helpful.  

The staff at the reception were a bit slow. Check-in took longer than expected. On one occasion, we stopped by at the reception to inquire about something, but the desk was empty.  We had to wait about 10 mins before someone showed up. 

The saddest part of my stay was that after we checked out, I realized I left my ring on the ring holder in the bathroom adjacent to the bedroom. I don't usually take that ring with me during vacation, but that time I did.  I called the hotel and got connected to the security. I spoke to Maria, who said the room we stayed in was already occupied. Anyway, to make the long story short, no one turned in my ring. I was quite disappointed, but I guess I just have to charge it to experience.

title: Avoid during renovations
text:
Had looked forward to staying at the storied St. Regis NY and had no idea the lobby and restaurants were closed. 

Arrived to no greeting at the front entrance (which was not clearly marked) at street level. There was a bell person (?) standing in front who just glanced at us as we tried to figure out how to enter the hotel. Same reaction from staff inside who looked blankly at us as we tried to navigate the confusing “go to second floor” then look for a temporary check in desk. This improved later as they had staff directing guests in the hallways.

Breakfast was served in a ballroom on the 20th floor (at least $50 per person for basic continental or American). No breakfast benefits offered for our Titanium Marriott Bonvoy status (though I see some reviews from other members who were offered free continental breakfast - why the discrepancies?!). The dining staff were very professional and courteous and were making the best of the situation (saw many people glance at the menu and leave).

The guest room was spacious and gorgeous with good amenities (including a Dyson hairdryer, which I loved), and everything I had dreamed about staying at the St.Regis New York. Housekeeping staff were also excellent.

title: Unacceptable experience, the customer is treated like a pigeon
text:
The experience at the St Regis this time was execrable. It’s a hotel I usually stay in when I’m in New York. The common areas of the hotel are being renovated and you have no lobby, no bar, no restaurant, no common areas and no communication on this subject, neither on the hotel website nor during the reservation. On arrival the person at the desk on the second floor, because you enter through a back door and have to take an elevator at the end of a dismal corridor to reach the desk for check-in did not inform me of the inconveniences like if that were normal. A second elevator then provides access to the bedrooms and a sort of lounge designed for breakfast.
In a word, non-existent attention, casual staff with little concern to manage the inconvenience.
I will no longer return to this Mariott group establishment

title: Disappointing stay at this storied StR in NYC.
text:
Struggled with rating and review but honest takeaway is that I would not stay at this location even if it was a redemption or reduced rate as too many service fails. 

Full disclosure: this was a 100k redemption by a Lifetime Titanium member. I used a suite upgrade to the Madison suite room 535.  The rate for that room was around $3105 per night.

There is construction going on. This was disclosed on website and I didn’t hear any noise. The effect is that the elevator and check in is puzzling although there are signs to direct guests. I confused which elevator bank to use more than once.  Would suggest signage in lobby elevator that it does not go past 2nd floor. Thought my key card was malfunctioning.

Doorman. Gave directions and friendly.  I think they offer some complimentary transportation service, never explained by front desk, doorman or butler. 

Valet. Spot on, helpful and prompt. Always present, busy  and engaged. 

Front desk: Mixed.  Varied from good to annoyed. Examples, inquired as to breakfast benefit. Told matter of factly that it was limited to continental breakfast because “construction prohibits preparation of an American breakfast”, not sure what this meant beyond meant to advise I was limited to that option?  Was told this benefit could be used via room service or on 20th floor temporary restaurant   Later advised restaurant was only option by morning staff. Requested a late checkout which is a hard guarantee for elites. Got a lot of pushback on this by young lady who had to “check” with someone in the back and then only begrudgingly agreed to 3P.  Other interactions with Suzanne were more positive. 

Butler: Greatest service failure . Stayed at StR in Middle East, Asia, Mexico and multiple US locations, shockingly poor interactions with our 4 to 12a butler. Examples: No introduction, no offer of any of touted services. Requested coffee service around 5P, best description I can give is the reaction you get when you press call button on a domestic economy flight. Almost visibly annoyed.  Small carafe of weak coffee. Tipped anyway, no reaction  Called housekeeping later for turndown service and ice in order to avoid butler, he called back, again annoyed. Brought ice, nothing else - Ignored our used tray and shoe shine bag by door on way out. Never used this or pressing service, bad vibe and didn’t want the interaction  Used overnight butler, requested coffee around 6A. Look tired, but was prompt and polite. Coffee was a large carafe and very good quality Tipped.

Room. Large, two bathrooms. Great bath products, towels and very good water pressure. Furniture, a little tired as were bed mattress quality.  View limited on 5th floor. Good sound proofing and beautiful building overall. Tile work in room, baths and lighting were aesthetic highlights. 

Location. Fantastic, close to Central Park and tons of dining and shopping options, best feature of this property. 

Dining/Elite benefits: We had breakfast on 20th floor. Our waitress was excellent and explained that even though the front desk tells customers that continental breakfast is only option, it’s actually $100 credit. Which makes the prior explanation by front desk even more annoying.  Why the weird hustle, just explain to your elites what is the allowance. The continental breakfast as the only option was messaged by two different staff members. Based on previous reviews, this is an ongoing problem at this location. Not sure why you want to annoy your elites as the messaging by front desk is to give impression your only option is a continental breakfast.  Why? 

So many options in NYC to include JW and RC at Battery Park, as mentioned, I would skip this location.  Based on other reviews and my experience, it is hit or miss service  when it comes to this location which is unforgivable for this legendary brand and this price point.

title: Under renovation, to be avoided
text: Very negative experience, we have been going to the St Regis for several years but this is the last time. The hotel is under renovation and they have not provided any type of DJ space for guests, meaning there is no lounge, there is no bar, there is no restaurant apart from the one for breakfast which is open for a few hours. Meanwhile, the spaces they would have available for guests are rented for special events. Totally unacceptable that a hotel of this standard does not communicate beforehand and has no space for guests. Big problems also with European DJ credit cards. Avoid

title: La beauté et le charme
text: I stayed 2 nights on points, was upgraded to a beautiful 1BR/2BA Madison suite, and loved it.  Yes; the hotel’s undergoing a lobby-floor renovation, but they waived the “destination” fee (usually $60 + tax/day; I don’t know for what) and provided free butler in-room coffee service.  Everyone was gracious and lovely, and the suite was divine and quiet.  Location:  idea for Midtown and UES attractions, dining and nightlife.   Bravo, St. Regis NYC!

title: Disappointed
text: Hospitality level was too bad at the entrance area and the reception. No guidance! We arrived at the hotel around 6:15pm. Nobody was at the entrance and we could not find the hotel entrance, then walked into the hotel and nobody was there. Also the staff was standing in front of the elevator and no greeting!

title: Awful customer service: hotel does not honor Platinum and above breakfast benefit
text: Hotel refusing to honor Platinum and above welcome amenity guarantee: Platinum, Titanium and Ambassador elites have a choice of 1000 points or complimentary breakfast for themselves +1 additional guest. I am a Platinum elite and had a reservation for Wednesday - Friday next week and was informed by the hotel via email that they will not be honoring this choice, as their restaurants are closed for renovation. However, they are still offering breakfast on the 20th floor and room service from 6am - 9pm. I spoke with three different individuals at the hotel today, including the front office manager Sammir, who informed me this was non-negotiable. If they had no dining option I would understand the refusal to offer the welcome gift choice, but they are still offering on-site dining, but for a fee: a la carte, estimated at a minimum of $50-$75 a person. 1000 Bonvoy points is not an acceptable alternative to a complimentary breakfast that would amount to $100-$150 a night, or likely over $300 for the two night stay I had. This is extremely poor customer service and as a result I canceled my reservation. This would have been my first stay at a St. Regis property and as a result of this asinine decision by upper management at this hotel I will not stay here or at any St. Regis property in the future.

title: Shine has worn off.
text: Once I posted on Trip Advisors that this was the best hotel I have stayed at . No more! the hotel has lost its luster.  I have stayed here over a dozen times, and this was the worst stay. Yes, they are renovating the lobby and bar, but that was not the issue. The service is going downhill, from the doorman to the lobby check-in, nothing special.  This stay was a surprise, a 60th birthday gift for the wife, no cake, no strawberries,  no champagne, no acknowledgment. In the past,  you didn't even need an event to get some kind of  gift in your room.  The hotel is not special anymore.

title: Excellent hotel in NYC
text:
Can't say enough great things about this hotel.

PROS:
Fantastic location - can walk everywhere
Nice upgrade to large Grand Deluxe Room
Super comfy beds, sheets, pillows
Excellent Butler Service
Great shower pressure
Nice blackout shades
Iconic bar - King Cole Bar, always a must stop to have a drink - (currently under renovation) - bartenders are GREAT!
All bellhops, doormen, valets were friendly and helpful
Concierge - Mohammed - was great!!

Was going to return now in April but under renovation so we will return again after it is done!

title: Still amazing even during the renovation — though I missed the King Cole Bar and Astor Court!
text:
My 5 night stay at the currently renovating St Regis New York with (previously mentioned) $477 BRG rate turned out to be an almost flawless stay as usual to my total surprise — even without the Astor Court restaurant, King Cole Bar, elite free breakfast benefit, or really much public spaces at all. I didn’t even get a suite upgrade for the first time ever here, upgraded “only” two categories to a Grand Deluxe Room, but it still turned out to be a very comfortable room and an outstanding stay. I loved it yet again.
#newyork #stregis #stregisnewyork #grandeluxeroom #upgrade #nofreebreakfast #renovation #ambassadorstatusmatters #aircon

I did consider changing to the RC NoMad after learning about the public spaces renovation and concomitant temporary suspension of the breakfast benefit only in mid-January, quite a while after my original booking. But the RC NoMad only guarantees 66 F in its rooms and suites as opposed to my knowing the St Regis easily can guarantee down to 60 F. Also, the St Regis concierge already had booked reservations for me at “impossible to get” 1* Tatiana, “almost impossible to get” 1* Kochi, 1* Rezdora, and the Polo Club, and “hard to get” 2* Aquavit — with the Polo Club across the street and Aquavit only down a block. And I had that incredible $477 BRG rate, to boot. The best rate I found for the RC NoMad was $680.

So even with the renovation, and even without the breakfast benefit, I stuck it out with the St Regis. And thank goodness I did! EDIT: the hotel later honored my breakfast benefit and refunded the $181 for my three breakfast charges at the hotel.

With the grand deluxe room normally costing about $1200 and my BRG rate of $477, I still had an Ambassador upgrade value of $3600 or so.  Pretty nice, all things considered. #ambassadorstatusmatters 

My grand deluxe room cooled as low as 58 F, but largely stayed at 60-62 F for the entirety of my stay. Just about the only mistake for the whole stay came when housekeeping accidentally reset my thermostat for turndown on my third night, but within 30 min of my return the air con returned to to my Arctic delight. #greataircon #airconworks 

Otherwise, my grand deluxe room was plenty spacious enough for me alone. But it would have been fine even with my husband, too. They had blacked out both windows as per my usual pre-arrival instructions, but the view was nice enough otherwise. They also had fulfilled all my other pre- arrival checklist requests, including pre-cooling the room to below 65 F for my arrival, extra bottles of room temperature water, a fan by the bed, and chocolate covered strawberries as my luxury hotel welcome amenity (along with a bowl of fresh fruit). #prearrivalchecklist 

The St Regis New York showers continue to be my favorite all time — with the most amazing soft but full water pressure ever. It’s a small space, but I love that water effect. I take unusually long showers here every time. The WiFi was also fantastic at usually 130 Mbps up and down. 

I ordered room service breakfast three times of my five mornings — costing me $72, $62, and $74 extra. At $0.007 a point, that would be just over 29K Bonvoy points. So the courtesy credit of 25K points from my Ambassador seemed a pretty fair compensation under the circumstances. But the room service items were delicious, hot, and prompt each time — I don’t think I waited more than 20 minutes for any. (The hotel also is operating a 20th floor ballroom as its breakfast restaurant, but I prefer room service.)

Room service continues until 9 pm during the renovation. Only once did I crave something for room service after that time. So that really was the only time I missed what usually would have been available to me. Not too bad. 

Butler French press coffee was delivered promptly and perfectly each morning. Due to the renovation, I didn’t insist on warm milk as I’d usually do here. The only other mistake of the entire stay was the butler once bringing two cups rather than one. Seriously. Not bad yet again. 

The butler service also unpacked for me on arrival after I went to dinner that first night. And they did shoe shine for me once. I didn’t need packing service at the end. 

Housekeeping was perfect (except for messing with my thermostat that one time) and invisible. They always brought more water, too. Turndown was done every night, usually timed to after I informed the butler I was leaving for dinner. 

I did complain to the hotel that their towels didn’t seem as plush as I remembered and the toilet paper was ridiculously thin and cheap. Housekeeping did bring me more plush towels, but a hotel manager called to apologize that they were using the Marriott provided chain-wide toilet paper. Clearly, that’s something they need to address for the luxury brands! 

All in all, I had another exceptional stay despite the renovation. I did miss having a drink at the King Cole Bar, but instead I enjoyed drinks at the Polo Lounge across the street and at the Chatwal bar (which wasn’t as good as before, so I won’t return). It was a little annoying taking the elevator on entry to the 2nd floor (where they have the temporary lobby, front desk, and concierge) and then walking to the different elevators to get to my 16th floor room, but I managed. Otherwise, it wasn’t that different for me. 

I tipped the front desk, butler team, concierge team, and housekeeping. They all did a really great job, not even considering the unusual renovation circumstances 

Would I stay again at the St Regis during this renovation? I have to admit that I might. It was still that good to me. And the air con, rooms, service, and F&B quality are as good as ever. Paying for the room service breakfast that good doesn’t bother me for a stay this nice, tbh.

But I can’t wait to see what the new public spaces looks like after they finish. Rumor is that they also will renovate the rooms and suites when they finish the public spaces, so stay tuned.

P.S. I did manage to visit and check out the RC NoMad for the first time after my lunch at nearby 1* Rezdora. Suffice to say that the mostly southern exposure windows for almost all rooms and suites wouldn’t make for the best or coldest air con experience for me compared to the much better air con at the St Regis. But it’s a very nice hotel otherwise with impressive modern decor for those that like that. And I absolutely love the NoMad neighborhood. The rumor is that the hotel will be acquiring the northern side of the building soon and will renovate that to add northern facing rooms and suites — which will be more appealing to me!

title: Branch
text: The atmosphere is great but the they should improve the menu on the bar side. Overall we had some fancy cocktails with my girlfriend. The hotel staff extremely nice as well the location is prime close to everywhere. The rooms are big which is soon good compare other hotels around.

title: Good and Not So Good
text:
The hotel and service are really nice. The room we stayed in was large and the housekeeping service was good and prompt.  We had a great checkin experience and the front desk team were friendly.  Our dining experiences at breakfast were nice (both in restaurant and room service) and the food was good. The bar as well was memorable since it was in one of my wife’s favorite movie A Devil Wears Prada. 

But two areas of opportunity and improvement 

1. We never met our butler even though it was hyped up so much. 

2. The billing for their fees is AWFUL and consistently fraudulent with my other experiences in Marriott properties recently. We didn’t get the appropriate discounts that supposedly come with the fee in terms of salon discounts and laundry discounts. And then fixing the issue was maddening and took at least a half dozen emails and two calls to resolve.  And then the management team never reached out to apologize despite my request and the escalation to Marriott itself WENT NOWHERE.  So just a warning: scrutinize your bill before checking out, as otherwise fixing a mischarge is not easy!!

title: Worst stay ever
text:
This place was such a disappointment
The front desk staff are horrible. Rude, nasty, unprofessional. I would never start there again. This is not a St Regis!!!  I checked in requesting connecting rooms, or on the same floor. I was on 9th floor friends on 4th floor. I’m a gold member my friend a platinum member. They didn’t tell us the lobby is under construction, so it was three elevators and side entrance to get in or out of hotel. 
I booked a friends and family rate so they treated me like crap. I had a confirmed rate of 590.00 they told me I had to pay 930 a night because my form was wrong. Total lies. They should have just honored it.  They gave my friend a 1,000 points for the construction. When I asked if I was getting that also, the front desk manager yelled loud in front of everyone, you don’t get it, you are gold member only. What difference does it make I have no idea. She said if I don’t like it they will cancel my reservation.  I should have left and went to the ritz Carlton. That place had class. I went there for a massage and was treated like a king. Everyone  was complaining at the front desk about construction. Then it was my husband 60th birthday celebration. They sent up procesco to my friends room wishing her a happy birthday. No one knows what they are doing there. When I called to complain she said ok I’ll take the procesco out of her room and bring it to you. I told them forget it we didn’t want anything from them. She said ok and hung up. Trust me don’t stay there. Run got your life. Go to the ritz I have never been treated like that in a long time. Almost ruined the celebration but we rose above. Disgusting behavior from management.

title: Disappointing Stay at St Regis NYC
text:
Just finished a 1 night stay at the St Regis NYC. As others mention, the hotel is currently being renovated and the usual breakfast location and the King Cole Bar are currently closed. I understand hotels need to renovate and I always appreciate it when finished. You would think because of this, they would step up their game to balance this disruption. St Regis is going a different direction. I have platinum status which gets you free breakfast. Not so during renovation! I was told my only welcome amenity to choose is the 1,000 bonus points. The equivalent of $9 lol. But no worry, I can pay full price on the 20th floor for the same breakfast. Would love to know the person at top that approved this. We went next door to the Peninsula and had a fantastic breakfast for $200. So instead of the St Regis giving me $50 to put towards an already expensive breakfast they rather irritate their brand loyal customers have us vote with our wallets instead. Again very boggling decision from upper management. 

The feeling of being nickel and dimed didn't start at check in, however. You get the usual precheck in email asking if you will be celebrating anything special. I stayed for Valentines Day and emailed them that I will be celebrating that with my wife. In return I was sent pdfs that had options like $24 chocolates and $180 for a dozen roses. Now I never expect for the red carpet to be rolled out, but cash rates were $1.2k for Valentines Day. Yes the room is great, the bathroom is beautiful, but is that worth that kind of price? This is NYC and the options are plentiful. A welcome glass of champagne or welcome glass of wine goes a long way in enjoying a luxury stay. 

Butler? who's that? Never heard from them.

They advised the renovations will be going on until August which makes this pretty unstayable in my opinion. Even so, the little things that I value when staying at a 5 star hotel are absent here. Even with an 85k certificate this isn't good value. If I paid $1.2k for the night I would be weeping into my expensive pillows. Also, no top sheet for the bed??

Too many places to check out in NYC that I can't imagine I'll be back in the next 10 years. I would need to hear this property was sold and is under new management.

title: Not the experience you would expect
text:
This hotel has nice rooms, friendly staff and an excellent location.

Unfortunately they are currently renovating the hotel so the lobby, restaurant, bar and sauna are unavailable. As a guest, you must enter through a side entrance and must take 2 separate elevators to reach the room.

When booking, no mention was made of the renovation, which meant that the stay did not meet expectations. We paid for a 5 star experience but didn't get it.

title: Don’t expect much….. if you have status go elsewhere
text:
Totally not worth the 85k cert plus points (105k points total). Small upgrade and they said due to the renovation they won’t offer the free breakfast but I could still go to the restaurant and get breakfast it just won’t be free (tell me how this makes sence). So basically, if you have status in Marriott stay elsewhere to use the benefits you earned. I’m Titanium with Marriott and used to be an Ambassador but started switching  my stays to Hyatt due to stuff like this in the Marriott brand.

-minimal upgrade 
- no breakfast (Titanium elite) 
- car service non existent (don’t expect a Bentley or anything at all for that matter) waited 30 min and just grabbed an UBER

(They will probably respond to this with their typical “I’m sorry you didn’t enjoy your stay,  please try again line”)

title: A Dump with Tinsel Lining
text:
As a Marriott Ambassador Elite for several years, I've stayed at many, many properties from the lowly Fairfields to Ritz's and many St. Regis properties. I've seen the great ones ..... and some that made me cringe.

This property falls in the middle, but slightly closer to the cringe end of the scale.

To begin, then really don't give any credit to your status for a potential upgrade, and believe me we did reach out several times .... and I booked over 275 nights last year so if I'm not getting a bump, neither are you unless you're some type of royalty or entertainment luminary.

The most important thing about this property is that they are UNDER RENOVATION, so many of the rooms are out of service. 
ADDITIONALLY,  the bar and restaurant are out of service as well, although they do have a meager selection available on the room service menu. A colleague ordered some chicken soup and ice cream and reported the chicken to be well overcooked and inedible. The ice cream was flavorless, as well.
If you stay here, plan on eating out or bringing your own sandwich, as you'll get nothing worth eating here, while the hotel undergoes month's of renovation.
They will not comp you for breakfast during this renovation for some reason (typically, Starwoods ALWAYS offers you a free breakfast as a reward ) but if you have really deep pockets they are now serving a PAY breakfast up on their top floor.

The room we received (they claimed upgraded) was rather smallish, and I would estimate roughly 300 sq ft. It was adequate for a single person, but certainly not more than two.
Bed was comfortable and bathroom was smallish but well appointed.

Room was NOT READY until about 5 pm, so if you get here early you may be unpleasantly surprised at how long you'll wait.

The hotel has historically beautiful details throughout the common area's with extensive marble detailing which does extend into the bathroom area's, but again the rooms are nothing special (at least ours wasn't) and for the astronomical cost per night you would normally expect much better value.
Additionally, the hotel is "landlocked" by office buildings, so you'll get no view of anything worth seeing. You would be well advised to keep your window shades drawn as well, if you don't want to wind up on some murky, perverted website.

This property has most certainly seen better days, and if you truly want a better taste of Manhattan, I would certainly suggest an alternate such as the Plaza or the nearby Ritz Carlton, both on top of Central Park. There are also many slightly lower category of Marriott hotels that would easily surpass the St. Regis, such as the Marriott Marquis or the Westin Times Square ...... or any of the dozens of independents that are scattered around Central Park.

The St. Regis is number 200 for a reason ..... and with the lack of culinary and lounge offerings for the next year or so, it probably will gravitate to #500.

Stay elsewhere, and safe and happy travels !

title: Two Nights of Luxury
text:
The St. Regis Hotel made my sisters' birthday a perfect celebration. First of all, we were able to check in very early (not always guaranteed even with status). We were extremely grateful for the upgraded suite accommodation. There were plenty of people to help make our stay nothing but the best including  the front desk staff, bellman and  our butler.

The suite was exquisite. There was. marble and beauty throughout the suite. It included updated high end furniture to sit and relax. It is a historical and classy boutique hotel. This hotel was on my bucket list and the St Regis exceeded my expectations.

The bathroom was like a mini spa. It was huge and gorgeous that included a rain shower and a separate tub. There was even a TV  inside the mirror. Very thick luxurious towels and robes were provided as well.

We opted for room service breakfast which was very delicious and delivered meticulously and timely. I suggest if you have an early morning event/ appointment to order your breakfast the night before. We did that and everything was delivered on time. There was so much food that we were literally not hungry until dinner.

The bed was extrememly comfortable and cozy with high end linens. If we didn't have scheduled events we could have lounged around all day in the beautiful exquisite suite.

What made our  stay the most memorable was how friendly and helpful the St Regis staff were with every single encounter. I would love to have a repeat at the beautiful St. Reigs.

title: Beautiful Room - Excellent Service - Lobby needs a refresh
text: I truly could have stayed here for weeks!  The room was very spacious and lovely with an amazing bathroom.  Service was fantastic - everyone was extremely helpful and the room was spotless.  I especially appreciated the Dyson blow dryer and comfy slippers.  The location is excellent - you can walk to wonderful shopping, restaurants and other attractions.  Currently the restaurant is under construction but that did not impact my stay in any way.  My only suggestion for improvement is the lobby area - there are limited places to sit or meet others, also the carpet at the entrance is worn - does not make a very good first impression.

title: Surround Yourself In A Grandiose Experience.
text:
The St. Regis New York is a hospitality institution in the heart of NYC. It's decor is fabulous as it shows off it's Beaux-Arts styled interiors that encompasses ornate gold wall detailing, frescoes, sparky crystal chandeliers and gilded everything. My Superior King was ravishing with a distinguishing aura displayed by a melange of old New York glam with European influences. Well preserved Art Deco, leather headboards, velvet sofas, stripped wallpaper, living & sitting area......everything is so fabulously impressive. The marbleized & gold bath is heavenly with rainfall shower and separate tub.  I look forward to the iconic King Cole Bar and the stately Astor Court when renovations are complete. The St. Regis is light on physical amenities but sports a modest fitness center; however, can't beat the personalized service each guest is assigned.
So, if you want to stay in a legendary NYC hotel with service fit for royalty.................
......then try the.................The St. Regis...........surround yourself in a grandiose experience.

title: Not what I expected
text: So 3 stars I feel is being really nice. My fiance surprised me with a trip to NY and we usually love St. Regis. We stayed here right before Christmas. The building itself is beautiful and the rooms are gorgeous! Another plus is the location. The service on the other hand not so great. The staff were not friendly or helpful. The breakfast was terrible. So don't waste your time eating there when there are so many good places you can go instead. My first meal was eggs Benedict it came out over cooked. The next day I got the avocado and burrata toast. I asked for them to remake and they joust brought me toast. So had to scrape the avocado off the old one which had already seeped into the bread. So I ended up just not eating. The servers were very rude and seemed to not want to be there. Also the hotel set out some hot chocolate and candy near the elevators which was a mess and also stale candy. I over heard a few other guests talking about how bad their stay was overall and they'd never be back and honestly I feel the same. Unfortunately not the St. Regis experience I expected.

title: 3 P’s ( PERFECTION, PROFESSIONALISM AND PEACEFUL
text: Scream to perfection. All the staff are very kind, helpful and they welcome you with a warmth smile. We enjoyed our stay in st. Regis Hotel New York, we stayed in Madison Suit and it’s so beautiful with stunning view. We also enjoyed the sunrise that peep to our window pane. Lovely stay.

title: Perfection in hotel
text:
Absolutely perfect as usual, and I have stayed there many times over the years.

Expensive, but it is worth it if you can afford it and want the luxury the hotel provides.

Yes, I would go again next time I go to New York City.

title: Best Upgrade Ever
text:
Stayed only for 1 night on a free night certificate along with some points at the end of December (I am a Platinum).  We checked in around 8pm with the lovely front desk agent and after a few minutes we received what I  believe is the best upgrade I have ever received. We went from a base room to the Bentley Suite.  This suite was fantastic and bigger than most apartments in NYC.  Needless to say everything about the suite was awesome.  After roaming around the suite we decided to go to the King Cole bar for a drink.  They really make it civilized at the bar.  Only a certain amount of people are let in so it never feels crowded or people on top of you.  The drinks while pricey were excellent. For breakfast the next morning we ate at the Astor Court which was included.  Food and service was on the spot. As part of the $50 destination fee you receive some $ amenities. In addition to a Laundry credit we got $50 to use at the salon. You don't have to use it for a treatment and instead my wife got some pricey shampoo to take home.

While my stay impression was helped by my massive upgrade, I can say all other aspects of this hotel are fantastic and it starts with the staff.

title: Paid with Points, Got Home and They Charged Me Cash Anyway!
text:
I stayed at the St. Regis New York between December 8-10th.  Yes, the front desk was pretty challenging to deal with, they were upsetting, but I used points-  a lot of them, nearly half of all my points to get my room.  I got home- after signing my folio for a total of $500.   Couple days later I see they posted a charge for $4884.00!   Unbelievable.  I don't know if they made a mistake, hoped I wouldn't notice, or just wanted to charge me $5000 and make it hard to fight this and give up and let them have my money?!   This hotel has taken things to a new level.  

I've now called the accountant, spoke to the front desk (surprise-  they were mean to me), and I'm challenging the payment on my credit card and ultimately I guess stop payment?   St Regis: if you're reading this-  please look me up, realize you double charged me, and just make things right.   Enough is enough-

title: Still No Resolve from January 2023
text:
Still no response from St. Regis.  I’ve called as advised.  Only for my call to continuously get passed around to no avail.
When I finally spoke with Oscar, I described myself and the situation surrounding my visit.
At first he didn’t recall our conversation.  Next, he chose to assume and insinuate that I was calling about my past experience and to complain.  He proceeds to tell me that I better not say I’m calling about a racial situation because he is a gay Latin or philliphino guy and he has NEVER encountered anything such as that from the staff there at the Regis.  I was appalled, to say the least.
I proceeded to tell him why I was calling.  Which was due to our last conversation on my last visit this past January, where he advised that when I come back I can repeat my treat at no expense to me.  — That the Regis would apply the same accommodations as a credit for my return.
He then proceeds to immediately cut me off and said that he now remembered me and that he would NEVER say such a thing.
I was furious but maintained my professionalism, and this was difficult.  So then he becomes dismissive of my call when I explain that we’re planning a repeat of our last visit and reaching out to him as he had previously instructed.  
He then tells me that what I’m stating isn’t possible but to proceed with putting it in writing to him.  I asked about a review with the upper management.  He tell me to include the general manager in the email, and most likely I won’t get to stay there, but ultimately it’ll be up to her — upper management. I’m going to send an email as advised.  However, I made sure to reserve those dates myself, just in case he tries some funny business with telling me that I won’t be able to make a reservation for that time because they are ALWAYS booked.  However, I went right online and easily made a reservation 🤔
I’m still appalled.

title: Disappointed and disillusioned
text:
This Hotel was always on my top favorite places to visit since it was the first St.Regis which would have to live up to its fame, glory and history… definitely be top notch… I believed. On our 5 day stay we were convinced otherwise. Having stayed as a loyal Titanium Bonvoy member in other St.Regis Hotels (e.g. Singapore) I had of course some kind of expectation, but this? 

Checkin was chaotic and we didn’t receive half the info needed. There was no note or some kind of welcome in the room. After first contact with the butler service they just didn’t pick up the phone and didn’t call back. We tried every day and even after informing front desk no answer. We asked for a water cooker for tee, since there was no tea/coffee service. It was broken. So we had to order hot water for 8$ from the room service which magically worked fine.  

Since we used our Bonvoy upgrade option, we got upgraded to a slightly bigger room next to the extremely loud and on weekends busy service elevators which I realized only after 2 sleepless nights. I talked to the reception that I would like to change our  room. The reception staff said that there was nothing available at this point and they would contact us until  14:00.

 Guess what… I checked the Bonvoy App and there were 5 different room categories available for our remaining stay… ! So of course nobody contacted us until 15:00 and I again had to explain myself at the front desk. 

Heureka, we got downgraded but at least we didn’t have to listen to the service elevator at night any more… amazing what small things can make one happy. Of course the butler service didn’t work on this floor as well. 

Breakfast in the restaurant also could not live up to the St.Regis standard, I even had doubt if the salmon was fresh since the plate smelled heavily like fish. 

Having paid an equivalent to about $1700 a night I can definitely not recommend this hotel, actually if I think about it…  unless there are some major changes I wouldn’t want to stay there even for free. DB

title: Absolutely Amazing Experience
text:
When we first checked in, there was some frustration in the line because it was after 4:00 and there were just no rooms available.  It was a busy weekend in December, and all of Midtown was packed.  Some of the guests in line were taking it out on the people working at the front desk, who were doing their best.   I am not sure how the people working check-ins were able to keep their demeanor based upon how they were being treated  - yes this is a 5 star hotel, but clearly they were slammed with dozens of people checking in at once.  Despite how busy it was, the woman checking me in was nothing but smiles as she searched for a room, unsuccessfully.   I told her to please not worry about it, I'd give her my phone number, and she'd contact me when the room was ready.    Meanwhile they took our bags, and we went for a cocktail nearby.   An hour or so later, our room was ready - not a big deal, not sure why others can't be more patient.   I'm not in NYC to hang out in my room.  Upon checking in, they acknowledged my Platinum Elite status and my birthday, and provided an upgrade.   

The room was absolutely fantastic.  Very luxurious, with a wonderful view of 5th Avenue.   They also gave us a $100 hotel credit to make up for the tardiness of our room - much appreciated!  The bed was extremely comfortable and the bathrooms very posh, and immaculately clean.  This was honestly one of the best hotel experiences that I've had, and I've traveled quite a bit, also having stayed at 3 other different St. Regis properties.  

The only thing that I would change is that the sole option for getting a cocktail in the hotel was at the Cole Bar, which ALWAYS had a long line to get in.  I am not going to wait 30+minutes to wait for a cocktail in Manhattan - plenty of other options, but I'm sure others would not mind.  Personally, I like to have something cozy and less trendy in the hotel I am staying in, but again - that's just a personal preference.  

Finally, the location is great if you want to be in Midtown.   Of course, very touristy, but that's to be expected.  It's very convenient to the major sites this time of year, such as Rockefeller Center, Saks, etc.  I'm more of a downtown person but it was nice to stay in a different part of Manhattan for a change and a quick and easy subway or cab ride to escape.

In summary, thank you, St. Regis New York, for a memorable stay and treating us so well.   Well done.

title: Best Hotel in New York
text: The past few days my wife and I have enjoyed experiencing the holidays in what I believe to be the finest hotel in New York City. Although we have stayed in many fine hotels in New York over our last 39 years together none of them have come close to everything the St. Regis offers. First, the location is absolutely the best in the city! Second, every meal we enjoyed either in Astor Court or the King Cole Bar the food was excellent and served hot. Next, the Room itself was beautiful and not only had a very comfortable bed, but the water pressure was superb in the shower and provided all the hot water you would ever want. But I would say more than anything else what made this hotel stay so special were the people that worked there. From the gentlemen that greeted you when you first arrived or when you said goodbye, to the front desk, to the butlers, to the waitstaff in the restaurant and bar, all of them were some of the most professional and friendly people you will ever meet. Honestly after three nights we really did not want to leave. Thank you St. Regis New York for exceeding any expectations we had for our stay and for a job well done!!

title: St.Regis NYC needs to train front desk staff
text: I experienced one of the worse St. Regis stay at the St.Regis Hotel New York.  For reference, I have stayed at many St.Regis locations around the world.  This NYC location used to be my go to hotel until this year.  The front desk staff definitely need more training, in particular this person name Sue that worked in the morning check in.  Regardless, the butler service and house cleaning staff were one one of the best.  I also dined at the restaurant many time. Dinner staff is amazing. I would go here for dinner by stay down the street at the Ritz.

title: Billing issues
text:
We  (2 adults and 3 children) stayed at the St Regis NY for two nights in mid November 2023. I initially made a reservation for a suite and a double room but when I called to inquire about connecting those rooms the hotel manager informed me that the particular reservations could not be connected and he can arrange for different suite and a different room. I agreed to pay additional $2200 for that and was assured it was all set. Upon arrival the check in staff informed me that the connecting room (double) is not ready/has issues with plumbing, and they need to move us to another configuration (no additional charge). We agreed to that and were finally checked in into a one bedroom suite on the 3rd floor, with a connecting single room, 303/305, the hotel considers that a 2-bedroom suite. Checked out two days later, my bill was for two separate rooms, total a little less than $10,000! I called the hotel, spoke with Tracey and was assured accounting will fix the issue and she will follow up with me. I never heard back from her and had to call her myself the following week. She again assured me that accounting fixed the over billing and I'll be receiving credit. So far no credit has been issued, going on more than 3 weeks.
Apart from the billing issue, the hotel is dated. Last time we stayed at it was in 2019 and nothing much had changed. Check-in staff was snobbish, the housekeeping was super friendly and butler was somewhat in between. 
The suite had a wonderful view of 5th Ave, the inside was a bit dated but very clean and housekeeping did a wonderful job organizing while we were out.
The last few times we were in NYC, we stayed at the Ritz Nomad and that will again be our choice moving forward.
I'm a long term Marriott Bonvoy member, platinum elite status and have been staying mostly at Ritz Carlton suites for the last couple of years while traveling to different destinations and wouldn't return to this property in the future. Not worth the anxiety about what could potentially go wrong before, during or after our stay.

title: A Disheartening Encounter at St. Regis New York: Unfulfilled Expectations and Neglected Needs
text:
As a dedicated patron of high-end hotel chains for nearly two decades, my recent stay at the St. Regis New York was not just disappointing, but deeply distressing. usually experiencing exceptional service at Ritz Carlton now Bonvoy hotels, I hold Platinum Ambassador status, our experience at the St. Regis was a horrible experince.

From the onset, our arrival was ruined by a demeaning encounter at check-in. Despite meticulously pre-arranging our stay, including wiring payment and exhaustive email communication, we were confronted with an unexpected and unwarranted demand to validate my corporate status. The staff's insistence on this during a holiday period, coupled with their inability to recognise the efforts we had already made to confirm our stay, was not just inconvenient but deeply humiliating. And that they expected we read through the hotels website terms and conditions before arrival, yet no one mentioned this in any of the emails (who reads hotels terms and conditions on the website), usually the booking confirmation and email confirmation will suffice. 

The handling of this situation by the staff member, Erik, was particularly upsetting. His inflexibility and apparent disregard for the nuances of our situation – traveling with a young child and an elderly person – was not only shocking but also set a tone of unwelcomeness that pervaded our entire stay.

This experience at the St. Regis did more than just inconvenience us; it dealt a severe blow to our confidence and sense of self-worth. To be made to feel so undervalued and judged, in an environment where we expected the highest standards of hospitality, was both disorienting and deeply hurtful. 

Further aggravating our stay were the repeated oversights in basic hotel services. Requests made in advance to the concierge and butler were ignored, and basic housekeeping needs were consistently unmet. The bizarre and unsettling incidents of our doorbell ringing in the middle of the night without explanation, and the apparent lack of adequate security, compounded our anxiety and discomfort.

In conclusion, our experience at the St. Regis New York was not only far below the expected standard of a five-star hotel, but it was also a deeply wounding experience that has left a lasting negative impact to me and a few members of our family. The treatment we received was unacceptable and has significantly marred our perception of the St. Regis brand. I strongly caution others against staying here, as the hotel's failure to provide basic respect and dignity to its guests is inexcusable. This stay was not just a failure in service; it was a devastating blow to our personal esteem and confidence. 

I would advise the hotel staff to not consider how they treat people by their appearance linking to wealth or their knowledge of someones wealth and treat everyone as equals - as the saying goes, never judge a book by its cover!

title: Overpriced and Underdelivered
text:
Husband and I go to NYC every year for our anniversary, always have great experiences and usually stay at the Essex or Chatwal.  Decided to change it up for our 20th this year because we loved St. Regis DC…wow, what a mistake.  St. Regis New York was nothing special, no good views (understandable for midtown, but the Essex can give you Central Park!!!). What was particularly abysmal was the “butler” service.  To be clear - we did not book for this service, but after being charged an extra $50 a day (included and additional, no way to opt out!), I expect at least the appearance of an attempt at “luxury”, nope.  Coffee took over an hour and we were charged for it (supposedly included). Shoes put out were buffed and put right back (not shined).  Laundry (again, pressing supposedly included) was literally folded and returned…with all its wrinkly glory, yes, I have pics.  Not to mention the car that you can use is a first come first served, etc.  I understand this sounds picky, but it’s only because I want to point out that this place is touted as something it is not.  Unless you are a live-in resident they could care less about service, there was no welcome, no butler service to speak of and we hauled our luggage ourselves due to them being busy.  

So take this as a warning: don’t expect luxury here!  Nobody was rude (had several great waiters at the Astor and a wonderful doorman), but nobody went that extra bit…just know that when you lay down $6000+ for a memorable weekend.

title: Do not hold your breath for the Butler!
text:
Snobbish staff! Very!
Checked in suite.
One of the 2 small and outdated TVs not working.
One of the 2 outdated telephones: unplugged.
Butler service means no service, No one shows up.
Below par breakfast where the omelette fillings are cold and the waiter forgets 50% of the order.
The worse: Concierge! Asked where could I I enjoy a traditional Thanksgiving dinner? Answer: I can give you some links!!! My thought: What would you say you do here?
Question; At what time does the NYC Thanksgiving parade start? Answer: 6:00 am. Wrong answer. 
Perhaps I am too demanding.
The property will undergo a renovation next year. It needs it, but...will service improve?

title: Best Hotel Stay and Upgrade Experience
text: I had the best experience at this hotel. I used points for this stay so my expectations were very low going in which helped with the overall experience. We originally had a standard room and asked if we wanted to wait for a suite. So we did and when it wasn't ready on time we were given $200 food credits. Unfortunately, the first suite wasn't ready and we were upgraded to an amazing corner suite with a view of the Empire State Building. The room was huge and just beautiful. The breakfast was amazing and they didn't charge us to have it delivered to the room (Platinum Elite Status perk)! The location is also perfect. Highly recommend this hotel.

title: Not the St. Regis I am used to.....
text: I have been staying at the St. Regis NY for over 25 years.  Service has always been excellent however I thought that housekeeping was not great: several items were missing in the bathroom.  In addition, as a Marriott Ambassador I used to always receive a "welcome back" note which did not occur this time.  I had the feeling that, since the hotel has had such high occupancy for months, the extra personal touch is not required.  On the positive, the breakfast team continues to be just superb!

title: Not great value for money
text: The room was over $1000 per night and I was upgraded. However the room had only a tiny window directly facing a grey wall. In general I felt that the hotel was dated and way too expensive for what it was, probably because of the location. Next time I will stay at a more modern hotel.

title: Didnt meet the world’s 1st St. Regis fame
text:
I can’t agree with the fame of good service. Workers were lost to give us any information and explain any facilities we wanted to use. 
Nice decoration and good location in the center of N. Y. 
But butlers were not too professional. Out of information about daily credits system. Coffees were delivered wrongly with wrong menu. All three days. 
Not Sure if we wanted to come back to this hotel. 
And the bathroom had not been cleaned well. I had to encounter someone’s hair all over the bath tub.

title: Amazing experience
text: We loved this hotel! It was spacious enough for a crib and room to entertain a toddler. We fell in love with their shower head and I have been looking for it online to purchase for my home. St Regis please provide the manufacturer of the shower head.

title: Great in every way!
text: This hotel is absolutely top notch in service, courtesy, attention to detail, and it is immaculate!  Fantastic location (55th and 5th), historic facility, it doesn't get any better than this.  Thank you, St Regis, for your very gentle care of me during my stay.  It was a joy!  (As always)

title: Lies, Lies, Lies
text: I verbally confirmed with the hotel and Marriott that breakfast was included after paying a very large fee for a suite. I also received written confirmation from the hotel that breakfast was included only to be told upon arrival they breakfast was not included and they would not honor their verbal or written word. The hotel representative who was assisting me apologized asked his manger if they could offer the breakfast that was promised at the time of reservation, but the manager rejected his request. Your honor is only as good as your word. Pretty poor service for an ambassador member.

title: So wonderful!
text: We just spent one night at the St. Regis and can't wait to go back. Such a lovely, elegant stay, and although the hotel was wonderful, it was the staff that truly made our stay special. Every single person - from the car valet, to check-in and every server could not have been nicer. We had breakfast, lunch and dinner at the Astor Court and it was all perfect - the food was elegant and delicious, the wait staff went above and beyond, and the atmosphere was so regal yet relaxing. It was my daughter's birthday and they celebrated it so sweetly. Prices were very reasonable too. We went on Marriott points and I was concerned when I read a previous poster said he was charged a $250 points conversion fee, that did not happen to us. Highly recommend!

title: Fallen from grace
text:
The St. Regis New York has a long-standing reputation of leading the luxury hotel scene with its opulently designed guest rooms and famed butler service. Times have changed. And so has the caliber of service and the overall experience one can expect from this hotel — it has fallen from grace. 

Be prepared to (1) wait hours for simple requests (ice and slippers) via the butler service; (2) return to a reorganized room and rollaway bed that you did not request (whoever requested likely experienced a long delay); (3) ask for firm pillows pre-arrival and on arrival only to be given pillows that had zero life to them, so I went and purchased one in order to sleep comfortably;  and (4) observe the wear and tear on guest room furniture and inoperable room features unbecoming of the brand and cost of $1000+/night. 

Once upon a time, beauty and superior service certainly made the case/value proposition to  choose this hotel but beware, you will likely leave dissatisfied and disappointed.

The St. Regis New York no longer reigns from on high.

title: Super disappointing stay
text:
I stayed at the hotel for 1 night as a birthday present from my family, and I was excited to celebrate my special day with my wife. We had heard about the signature experience at this hotel, complete with a dedicated butler.

Upon our arrival, we were informed that our butler would meet us to explain this special service. However, we waited in our room for two hours without anyone showing up. When I ventured to check out the view from our room, I was shocked to discover that it overlooked scaffolding, trash, and construction debris (photo attached).

Later, on our way back from dinner, we informed the front desk about the no-show from the butler. Instead of addressing the issue, they simply asked me what I wanted. The next day, during check-out, I spoke with the manager who offered apologies and promised to comp our breakfast, which had already been paid for in the booking.

However, when I reviewed my credit card bill a week later, I noticed that the hotel had charged me for breakfast, despite the earlier assurance that it would be waived. This is technically a double charge since the reservation included breakfast. This prompted me to call the hotel to resolve the issue. Unfortunately, I was transferred and placed on hold for an extended period before speaking to someone who could assist. I was able to get the breakfast waived from my card but it was still charged in the original booking.

Given that this was supposed to be a luxury room experience, I must say that this entire ordeal was truly disappointing.

title: Gilded Age NYC Luxury and Service
text: My first time at a St Regis and I was impressed. Terrific hotel for a midtown business trip. Gorgeous gilded age interiors, large room that are traditional but very comfortable. Everyone has who works there is very friendly. Butler service is a great bonus for laundry coffee and other requests. Breakfast was excellent. I would definitely return

title: Very nice, but be wary if using points to stay.
text:
Titanium member of Marriott and have had the good fortune of staying at top hotels around the world.  The St. Regis NY was nice, but I expected more from the flagship hotel.  Don't get me wrong, it was great to be able to stay at the St. Regis where it all started, but I am torn on what I got for the price.  It was definitely a beautiful hotel, but a bit tired and dated.

The good - staff was excellent in all respects except for the front desk check in.  Patrick out front, Frank and some of the other folks who brought room service were all excellent.  The front desk staff though for check in was lacking.  They were understaffed at night and allowed people to jump the line to front, walked away while we were waiting to escort visitors upstairs, it was chaos.   Rooms were large by NY standards, well equipped, very nice decorations, bed was comfortable as was the down comforter and pillows.  Adequate closet size and hangers.  Bathroom very big with tub and shower, great water pressure.  Bonus was free shoe shine each day and two items pressed each day for free from the Butler service.  Cleaning staff was also excellent, room was made up twice a day.  Room service was very fast and always friendly.  Nice touch was the messages they put on the coffee foam.  Internet speed was okay and was able to conduct work on a laptop without issue.  Also, location is excellent, easy walking distance to Central Park, 1 block to the MOMA, a couple blocks to the metropolitan museum.  

Not so good - the first thing was there is no coffee maker in the room.  I appreciate that this is a high end hotel, but I have seen Nespresso's in everything from a Ritz, and Intercontinental and the Peninsula.  It is evident it is a money maker for the hotel.  Small pot of coffee and a latte was about $34.00 delivered and a 20 minute wait or so.   I used points to pay for three nights which was about 500,000 points.  When you check in, they ask if you are familiar with the resort fee but they don't say how much it is.  I believed this is what is typically called a destination fee that a lot of hotels charge daily for staying.  It did not indicate anywhere on the website during booking that there would be an additional charge for using points.  In fact, that is the purpose of using points - to avoid the cost.  At check out, I was handed a bill that reflected a $250.00 charge per night that was labeled point redemption charge.  This was added to the $50 daily usage charges and taxes.  So my free nights that I used points on ended up costing about $1,000.00 plus the points.  I appreciate that we got a great stay for what is arguably a low price, but for someone who may not be able to afford the money would really be put in a bad spot.  At the very least, when a person is redeeming points on the website, they should be told about the $250.00 point charge so they can make an informed decision before arriving at the hotel.  Seemed a bit shady to drop this at the end.

For anyone who stays here, if you need a quick and very good place to eat, I would recommend the Spanish place about a half a block of 55th.  Come out of the hotel, turn left, cross the street, and you will see it in the middle of the block on the right hand side next to Five Guys.  Food was excellent and authentic.  Definitely a great meal.  One other place would be the same route but about three blocks and on the right hand side of 55th, called Wagamama.  This is a ramen/Asian restaurant that had some amazing food.

Also, do not use the concierge for arranging a driver to the airport.  A cab ride to JFK is about $75 now.  A car service is around $125-150.  Arranged through the hotel, they charge you $250.00 to your bill.  Better off arranging on your own.

I would consider staying here again, but I want to see how the Plaza, Peninsula or Mandarin stack up first.  I have done both Intercontinental Hotels in NYC, the Sofitel,  and one Ritz and this would be about the same to me. It just wasn't the experience I was expecting from a hotel of this prestige.

title: True luxury with kind employees
text:
This was simply the finest hotel experience I've ever had. From the doorman to the butler, concierge to the maître d', everyone was exceptionally kind and attentive. The room was immaculate and in perfect condition. Every common area was gorgeous, dripping with history,  and well-maintained. By the end of my stay,  the staff had come to know me and took time from their duties to come over to say goodbye. I can't imagine a nicer staff.  I had meant to pay this Tebow at the time, and it never made it out of my drafts, but the memories are still fresh because of how wonderful my stay was. Standout employees were Kevin at the concierge desk and Lenny at the door. Every single server at the Astor Court restaurant was so personable and kind. 

If you are wavering between the St. Regis and The Plaza, don't hesitate in choosing the St. Regis. I find it to be a superior experience in every way, and I so look forward to my return in February.

title: EXCELLENT HOTEL & FANTASTIC STAY!
text:
We cannot say enough great things about this property.  Here are the PROS and CONS:

PROS:
Room: Grand Luxe Room was very nicely sized, well laid out, large bathroom with plenty of vanity space, good amount of closet space.
SLEEP: Bed is amazingly comfortable, bedding is divine. We tried to buy the sheets and bedding online but they are sold out LOL
BATH: Double sinks, separate bath and shower, excellent water pressure!
AC: worked great the entire time, slept well
Butler: Dolores was excellent!
Housekeeping: everything was clean and tidy
Bell / Valet / Door: Tom, Lenny and the rest of team at the front greeted us warmly and  assisted with luggage and directions, excellent service!

title: Luxury at its finest!! If you’re looking for the best, no need to look further!
text: Your wish is their command. The staff goes above and beyond the call of duty. They offer some of the most incredible suites that exist anywhere in New York City. Their one-of-a-kind suites are the epitome of luxury, fit for royalty and beyond even!

title: Truly 5-Star on 5th Avenue
text: Very impressive hotel! The room was mind blowing, the very best quality. They roll out the red carpet for titanium elites with a whooping $92 breakfast credit (you’ll need it) and a beautiful dessert deliver on arrival. They upgraded our room to a lovely corner facing 5th Avenue. It was definitely the full ‘St. Regis’ experience we’d hoped for! 🙌🙌🙌. My only feedback would be the bath amenities. I didn’t care for them. In Italy they use Aqua Di Parma at the two St. Regis there and they’re really wonderful products.

title: A high bar for "perfect stay"
text:
Wow what a wonderful weekend at St Regis NY.

We chose it as our wedding venue and I was at first a bit hesitant to book multiple rooms and nights for all the people involved. Our event coordinator Regan has been nothing short of amazing and most accommodating, but I wasn't sure what to expect when it comes to the stays.

As it turned out our stay went way above our expectations. We all know things tend to go off track no matter how well you plan ahead. On check-in we already had luggage mix-up due to our own fault, and Michael was most helpful and courteous in handling that. George and the other butlers stayed on top of our requests throughout the weekend, everything from garment pressing to clearing out the mini-fridge for extra space late at night and last-minute shoe-shining.

The hotel is simply gorgeous. The Madison suite we stayed in was enough to host the entire bridal party and the vendors for staging. But even the basic superior room is amazing. We don't usually have a high expectation for hotel food but the restaurant here makes us already talk about coming back just for that.

The only hiccup we had was some unrecognized minibar charges. But a call to the hotel the following Monday quickly cleared that up. 

All in all this stay was a highlight and will be part of our fond memories of the wedding weekend in the years to come. And I'm sure we will be back in the not-too-distant future.

title: Possibly the most spectacular hotel experience of your life
text:
Last weekend we went to NYC and stayed at the St. Regis Hotel at 5th Avenue and 55th Street.  This is our third visit and I can understand why it is considered “Manhattan’s Best Address.”

The hotel takes you back to another time, when hotel rooms were quite large, bathrooms were marble opulence was expected.  The lobby has an overhead mural, copied from Michelangelo’s painting of the ceiling in the Sistine Chapel in Rome.  The lobby has a brass, wall mounted mailbox, for the letters you will be writing on the hotel stationary in your room.

Two of the unique features that set the hotel apart are butler service and the house cars.  Every room has a butler, or at least part of one.  Our butler on the 16th floor introduced herself and asked how she could help.  We opted for their break French press coffee, which was promptly delivered.  Your butler will unpack and repack for you if you like.  The phone had a button labeled “butler.”  You press it and they are summoned.  Our butler has worked at the hotel for 16 years, as I recall.  It might have been longer.

The house cars are available midday and in the evening.  If you want to go so where in about a ten block radius, the doorman will get one to take you.  The cars are usually lined up outside and are late model black Mercedes S class sedans 

The hotel charges a $50/day resort fee.  This can be spent in various ways including the Astor dining room, but not the King Cole Bar.  However, you can have cocktails in the Astor Dining a room, no problem.  FYI:  wine is about $22/glass.  Popcorn is the least expensive item on the bar menu, priced at $16.

Are there minuses?  The hotel is expensive, but it is overwhelmed by the pluses.  This is our favorite hotel in NYC.  We look forward to our next visit.

title: They don’t care
text: Terrible experience.  Our original flight was cancelled and they don’t give you a number to the actual hotel in your confirmation email (just Marriotts 800 number) and after being on hold for 15 mins I figured that since we were staying for a week that everything would be fine showing up a day late.  Nope.  They rented our room out from under us so when we got there the next day at 11:30 pm they told us that the only rooms still available were $15,000 a night “designer suites” and when I asked to simply stay in that room until the next morning just so that we didn’t have to deal with finding another hotel at 12 am they told us “room price integrity” wouldn’t allow for them to do that and put us out on the street.  The next day when we showed up they told us the room would be ready by 4 pm but when we came back at 4 pm to get our room keys, they told us that the room we are in had a late check out of 4pm and they didn’t know when the room would be ready.  We have an event in two hours and won’t likely have time to get ready for that.  For all this hassle, they offered only two drink tickets at their bar.  I’ve stay at many high end resort properties and I’ve never been treated so poorly.

title: Great Customer Service
text: Outstanding in every way.  We used to come here a lot pre-COVID. It was our favorite NYC hotel. John from Food and Beverage has made our stay memorable like has done for our previous stays!  Hats off to wonderful customer service.

title: A Truly Disappointing St. Regis
text: A truly disappointing St. Regis experience. My friends and I visited St. Regis New York for 3 nights during the beginning of July. The experience upon check-in was not impressive. My husband and I are huge St. Regis fans, we have stayed at various St. Regis hotels around the globe and were very impressed with each of them. We thought the New York location would be the St. Regis of all St. Regis, but our expectations did not live up to reputation, at all. Being a Marriott Ambassador, I have communicated with my ambassador prior to arriving to the hotel our itinerary, special occasions and etc. Our ambassador confirmed the hotel received all the information requested and are looking forward to our arrival. Upon arrival, there was no door man, I had to carry my luggage up the steps, spin the spinning door by myself all in July heat. At this point, I am covered in sweat, front desk had no idea of my prior arrangements with my ambassador so I had to repeat everything over again. We requested dessert to be sent up to our room one night and our butler was so rude that he literally threw to food tray to us. We were here to celebrate two birthdays in two rooms, no acknowledgment of the celebration whatsoever. King Cole waiter was extremely rude. The most frustrating thing was that, my ambassador has already confirmed a late checkout for my friends room but during checkout day, our friends had to run back from Soho to pack because a late checkout was taken away. Our stay at the St. Regis New York was not a relaxing experience, if anything, it was a very stressful one! Way to go to ruin two birthday celebrations. The building is very nicely maintained, the rooms as well. However, the hotel lacks the service and experience a St. Regis truly represents. We will be returning to the Ritz Central Park for our New York visits.

title: Walmart Experience at Bergdorf prices
text:
Two doormen stationed at the front entrance saw us retrieving our luggage from the cab trunk,  but made no attempt  to help.  I had checked in a day earlier and was great full that the room  was made available at 12 PM .  They  did tell us there was no view; I was okay with that  as we are in NY regularly and at this trip it was not a priority.  I haven’t stayed at this hotel in a few years,  but remembered the excellent butler service and lovely accommodations,  and was looking forward to it.   The checkin felt like something one would expect at a  Highway motel.  No explanation of any services, no welcome drink,   no Butler introductions,  nobody accompanied you to the room or directed you to the elevator.

The room had the tiniest window,  with a curtain without a valance (# 1406) facing a wall a few feet away. No Natural light what so ever.  The leather head rest on the bed was ripped on a couple of spots. It had only one not very comfortable lounge chair in a fairly large king room.  So if you are a couple, you cannot even sit together for a cup of coffee.  In the past at checkin the butler would introduce themselves,  offer coffee , tea etc and make sure you were satisfied with the accommodations.  

We had ballet tickets for a matinee,  so initially decided to just go with the flow.  Went  for a quick lunch at the Astor, paid  around $170 for 2 ceaser salads, a bloody mary and  a glass of Duvel Leroy Champagne.  I have no problems paying premium prices  for value ,  but $28 for a Bloody Mary with a  celery stalk garnish and stoli vodka? They claimed to have invented it , but definitely not  worth the price. 

When we returned back from the ballet and returned to the room ,  it seemed really depressing.  They call it an interior room ,  but it could easily be in a windowless basement.  We requested a room change and requested to speak to a manager.  We were told the manager was downstairs and would call us back.  We were going to dinner,  so left the front desk our cell number.  The manager ever returned the call.  On our return when we requested a room change, we were told that they were completely sold out.  At this point we were exhausted an decided to just let it go and returned to our room for a  good nights sleep.  It was around 10:30 PM,  and there was a continuous loud rumbling sound.  When we called the front desk , we were told that the noise was from their service elevator which was being  used  a lot that night as 2 of their 4 passenger elevators had been broken for a couple of days.  They offered to now move us to another room.  So at 11 Pm we had to get dressed and pack up to move to another room.

The new room (1903), had a moldy smell.  Got up next morning with a back ache as the bed was not comfortable.  In the morning the moldy smell seems to have gotten even worse and I did  report that.  I was told it was because of air conditioning!  We called the butler for coffee in the morning.  The French press coffee arrived with cups saucers and milk.  You would expect at least some cookie or something to accompany the coffee ,  but they brought the bare minimum.  No little flower stem on the tray etc.  the butler said that he forgot the spoons for stirring and would bring one,  but never returned.  

We had breakfast at Astor court,  and here the service was good.  I forget the name of the lady who served us,  but she was excellent.  Brought some excellent grape  fruit concoctions before the main corse.  The eggs Benedict were also perfectly cooked.  She offered to pack the pastries for us that we hadn’t touched without are asking.  The professional and sincere service she provided was our expectation from rest of the staff.

The elevators and the elevator banks at the hotel are not air conditioned and it can get very sweaty while waiting for the elevator on a hot day and especially when 2 of the 4 elevators are not working.  Their excuse for this  is that it is a very old hotel.  I have stayed in 5 star hotels older than this all over the world,  and they have invested in modern technology like air conditioned elevators,  electric curtains etc.   Not sure,  that because this is  now a Marriott franchise, and the focus is on short term quarterly profit and CEO bonus,  focus  is not on reinvestment in the property and attention to detail.   

My advise to anyone  paying  for a hotel at this rate is to consider the Four Seasons,  Carlyle,  Peninsula etc.   It appears a lot of  the clientele here are the Marriott point collectors,  who stay at regular Marriott for business and then use their  points  to book a stay here.   

Overall this  was a very disappointing stay and I feel that the top management here  needs  thorough retraining  or be replaced.   It’s a pity that this one time landmark luxury hotel is falling apart.   Just having crystal chandeliers in the room doesn’t make  a hotel 5 star!

title: Good, iconic hotel, but…
text:
Overall, I enjoyed my stay at the St. Regis New York. The location is perfect, ‘hardware’ stunning and service top-notch. Rooms are very generously-sized, stylish (with an old-world vibe) and equipped with all amenities I could wish for. 

So why not 5/5? First and foremost reason: the junk fee (aka destination amenity fee). It’s 50USD++ per night and designed such that it’s utterly useless to me. You get 50USD daily food&beverage allowance (that cannot be used at the hotel bar - wtf?) and otherwise rather pointless perks like a laundry credit. To their credit, they removed the fee for one of the two nights after I complained. Also, I had the impression that elite treatment is limited to what they need to do - definitely not comparable to what Asian or even European hotels deliver. Breakfast was also not what I expected from a place that retails close to 1,000 bucks a night. I think the orange juice was not even fresh on the first night, but tasted like that disgustingly artificial stuff from the fountain… On the second night, it was better, but also not great.

So would I come back? Maybe yes, if the price is right. If they got freshly squeezed juice, worked on their Elite treatment and dropped the junk fee, I would probably be back 😊.

title: Ruined our wedding night
text:
I was really really disappointed from this hotel!!! A Friend of my husband sponsored a night at this hotel for our wedding night exactly a year ago for July 6th. We got to the hotel at 5:30 AM all excited to stay at a 5 star hotel one of the top hotels in Manhattan. In the presidential suite 
we knew we weren't going to get there too early but we had a late check out and hoped to sleep till then.

At 8:30 am we heard really loud noises going on right outside our window. I look outside our room window and there was scaffolding outside with 2 men doing construction!!! We both decided we couldn't sleep like that, packed up our belongings and went to front desk. By the front desk we complained about the noise and were told that they are so sorry and were promised another night and/or a refund. We understood that such stuff could happen and we didn't want to ruin our first day together after our first night was ruined. So we accepted and left.
We still never got the refund or a night free and when our friend who booked the place requested it he was told too bad 👎. 
The service of this place really disappointed me. They ruined our first night and promised compensation and then never delivered on their promise. Service is everything nowdays and they just don't deliver....

title: The St Regis New York never disappoints
text: Just had another great stay (from start to finish) at the wonderful St. Regis New York.    From the bellmen, to the front office staff, to the butler and housekeeping staff, to the incredible service in the King Cole Bar our stay was top notch.  There are so many high end choices in the best city in the world, and you can truly never go wrong with the St. Regis.  Can’t wait for our next trip back soon.

title: St. Regis New York - a hit and miss for me
text:
