I was excited to book the St. Regis for my recent trip to New York as I'm a big fan of other St. Regis locations that I've stayed at.  The butler service, and anticipating that my Marriott Ambassador status would add some additional perks, made me happy to pay out of pocket for the pricy rate.

Unfortunately, I was largely disappointed by the experience - what I hoped would be a

Some highlights - the room was gorgeous and extremely clean - housekeeping staff was really attentive.  Loved the bed and took advantage of the deep soaking tub.  I used my welcome gift of daily breakfast at the restaurant each morning, and enjoyed the wonderful waitstaff.  Location was great, but to be honest, there were many other hotels in the neighborhood that I wish I had considered

Some disappointments - I checked available rooms for my nights on the app after I had checked in and saw that there were upgraded rooms/suites available.  With my Ambassador status an upgrade to best available standard suite should have been given.  I was also told to wait in my room once I had checked in and someone from the Butler service would come and talk me through the service.  This never happened.  I tried using their paging system to see if someone was coming, but never got a response.  Since I had dinner reservations I gave up and didn't end up using the Butler service at all throughout my 5 night stay.

Sad to say I won't be booking a stay here again.

title: Did not meet expectations
text: Did not meet my expectations service wise. Workers were a little rude, only a few were truly nice and kind. The room are beautiful like the hotel but other than that, the food isn’t amazing either. I’d recommend the ritz Carlton or palace hotel if looking for great service and ultimate luxury.

title: Honor Bar Rip Off
text: The hotel itself was nice and the staff (other than at the end) was great.  I never write reviews but am angry enough to do this one.  I'm a platinum Marriott member and decided to try the St. Regis within the Marriott family for a change of pace.  Everything was fine, if a little stuff, until check out.  While at the airport I reviewed the bill and found two bogus honor bar charges for a total of $180.  We had had one half bottle of base level wine.  When I called, I was told that the bogus charges would be lifted and we would just be charged for the wine.  That was fine.  $65 is steep for average wine but I get it; mini bar at the St. Regis.  But what makes me angry is the hidden 20% restock charge.  Add the tax and its $90 for a half bottle.  I'd happily pay the $65 and the tax, but the idea of paying another 20% service charge for literally opening the mini bar.  Just BS.  Honestly, its not even the money, its the idea of it.  Tell me what you're going to charge and I can make a decision.  It's the BS hidden fees.  Never again.

title: Lovely NYC weekend
text: My husband and I came to NYC for a weekend getaway. The St. Regis made the visit perfect. Beautiful hotel. Nice and accommodating staff. Room was clean and comfortable. We ate dinner at Astor which was good. The waiter and hostess were so nice. Thinking of having a girls getaway with my daughter this summer.

title: Unforgettable Guest Service
text: Christina from the front desk provided an unforgettable experience at The St Regis.  My wife and I were celebrating our 10th wedding anniversary.  Christina treated us as if we were family and provided the best hotel experience we have ever had! Thank you Christina. John and Sara Papa

title: Continued disappointment.
text: Great hotel, great location. As a long time loyal Bonvoy member I have been greatly disappointed that we are never upgraded , and NEVER able to check in at the designated time. We have always visited on our anniversary in June and have never been acknowledged on our return. Our final straw was that using COVID as an excuse they didn't offer WRAPPED chocolate or fruits with a peel as a welcome. Sorry but loyalty is a two-way street, and they have lost me as a member.

title: Che stile
text: Bellissimo Hotel, rimani estasiato già a guardarlo dall'esterno. Una volta all'interno il personale si dimostra subito prodigo a fornire ogni tipo di assistenza. Ottimo il bar dell'hotel, consigliato!

title: St. Regis New York
text: First time at St. Regis, smooth check in and an amazing upgrade to a suite. The suite was clean and spacious- lovely stay. I gave four starts for customer service at the restaurant and the bar. They didn't have our dinner reservation, food and drinks weren't as impressive, service - they were trying. We continued our evening at the bar and I've never seen so unhappy and uncommunicative bartenders. I would expect for $28 -$36 cocktail at least good brand alcohol. What is on dispose is not what was under the bar making the drinks.  Everything else was really good and overall the stay was pleasant.

title: Another amazing Ambassador stay and Astor Suite upgrade
text:
My “friends and fine dining” week at the St Regis New York was another great success! (This and the StR San Francisco are my favorite city hotels in the USA.)

The St Regis New York just oozes Manhattan luxury to me. It’s really hard for me to consider staying anywhere else in the city. But I always try to find weeks when rates are lower than usual to indulge.

The hotel kindly upgraded me from an entry level superior to a Grand Deluxe upon checking in via the app 2 days prior to arrival, and then upgraded me again to an Astor Suite the morning before my arrival. That would be a $7000 Ambassador upgrade value for those keeping score (on top of an already amazing $650 AAA rate for this hotel). 
#ambassadorstatusmatters #stregis #newyork #stregisnewyork #kingcolebar #billsalltimefavorites #suiteupgrades 

The hotel offered me 4 pm late checkout, as well. 

The suite was pre-cooled below 65 F as per my #prearrivalchecklist — but quickly went down to a lovely 60-61 F for the rest of my stay. WiFi was blazing fast at 120 Mbps. Shower pressure is always incredible here; despite the small shower stall, this remains one of my 3 favorite showers in the world. #amazingshower 

I had a lovely fruit bowl and chocolates welcome amenity arrive just after my arrival. 

The fantastic concierge team helped in advance of my stay with dinner reservations at 3* Per Se, 2* Jungsik, 2* Gabriel Kreuther, 1* Cote. They also assisted with lunch at nearby Limani. 

While my King Cole bar stalwart, George, was out with a shoulder injury, the rest of the team always secured me a table — for myself or with friends. Drinks at the King Cole are part of my NYC ritual. 

Butler morning coffee service was always prompt — though over the weekend the hotel operator was a little clumsy helping to arrange it. They don’t normally include hot milk here, but they always do it for me when I ask. I only packed a carry on, so I never availed myself of butler unpacking and packing services (or shoe shining). 

I never actually asked about the breakfast benefit value for room service (which I did every morning but one) or at Astor Court, but I had assumed it was the same $140 value for up to two persons as it was during my stay last May. Regardless, all of my breakfast orders from $70-125 were removed from my bill at checkout. Breakfasts always were prompt, hot, and delicious. Service at Astor Court was a bit slower for Sunday brunch but otherwise was lovely. The strawberry cream French toast was divine. 

Housekeeping was flawless. Turndown service was great, as well. 

I had a minor but noticeable noise issue the last two mornings of my stay — as they were literally digging up the street direct outside the hotel below my window (12 stories below). A very short term issue, I’m told. 

I also enjoyed a spa treatment at the Peninsula just across the street. Extremely convenient, indeed. 

It wasn’t perfect, but it was pretty close — yet again. I tipped the butlers, concierge, housekeeping, and front desk very well, indeed. 

I’m already looking forward to my next stay.

title: WOW
text: We stayed at this property in late December 2022.  We received an upgrade and we were totally in awe of our beautiful room - 2 bathrooms, living room, separate bedroom, large, walk-in closet, kitchenette.   Our check-in process was smooth and the staff were very friendly and helpful.  Enjoyed appetizers and drinks in the restaurant - decent service although they were short-staffed.  This hotel no longer allows you to apply the $50 mandatory "service fee" to drinks at the bar but you can apply it to the restaurant, meals, the spa.

title: This is the grand hotel experience
text:
This past weekend we stayed at the St. Regis Hotel in New York for a pre Valentine’s Day weekend getaway.  We had a great time,

The hotel is expensive, but it fits into the category of ultra luxury grand hotels.  We paid using Marriott Bonvoy points. They have courtesy house cars that will take you places.  They have lots of staff.  Every room has butler service.  You push a button on your phone and they appear.  Someone will hail you a taxi and another someone will load your bags into the trunk.

The hotel rooms are huge compared to other hotels.  The bathrooms are marble.  The table lamps are controlled by a round disk you to turn them on off off.  The lighting system is sophisticated.  We have stayed here before and the best coffee we have ever tasted is the French press coffee brought by your butler at your request.

Bonvoy members at our level get breakfast included because there is no concierge lounge.  I am not sure if this is true for all bonvoy levels.  Breakfast can be served in your room or the Astor Dining Room.  The American breakfast runs $46.  Your included breakfast is either the American breakfast or a $46 credit towards other selections.

The level of service is amazing.  We packed a picnic, which we intended to enjoy in the room.  We asked our butler if they could provide plates, napkins and cutlery.  He asked what time we wanted to have our picnic.  At the appointed time, he rolled in an entire dining table with two places set on a white tablecloth complete with butter, rolls and a rose in a vase!

There are negatives.  The hotel has a $50/day destination fee.  This can be used in the restaurant, but not the King Cole Bar.  We learned that on our previous visit.  We decided to have dinner in the restaurant.  The $50 fee was applied vs. the bill, which is a good thing.  However , you cannot combine and then apply the two $50 fees.  It’s $50 that needs to be spent independently each day of your stay.

This is a grand hotel.  Tipping is part of the grand hotel experience.  In my opinion. You tip everyone you encounter who does something for you.  We tipped the butler when he collected the table, the person who cleaned our room, the bellman, the driver of the courtesy car and the doorman.  This included our restaurant server too.

As you can tell, we like the hotel.  It’s an ideal place for celebrating a special event.

title: vacaciones navidad 2022
text: Maravillosa la atención desde el primer momento, situación del hotel inmejorable personal  para ponerle de nota un 10,en todos los servicios, habitaciones impecables y confortables ,mueble bar a punto todos los dias

title: Crown Jewel
text:
The St. Regis NYC continues to shine bright setting standards for the entire industry. The hotel boasts iconic, spacious and indulgent accommodations exalting the true definition of luxury. The experience is incomparable due to unparalleled service from its legendary butler team that takes guest services to the next level. Upon check-in, the front desk team was undoubtedly overwhelmed with a number of last-minute bookings and remained patient working to get guests placed in available rooms while consistently providing others with status updates. It was like watching a world-famous orchestra on stage. 

Its reputation and brand remains indisputable, from the front house to the back house, it is white glove treatment all the way. This is where luxury resides.

title: Mid...at best.
text:
I fully realize that if you are complaining about the St. Regis, you honestly need to reevaluate your life.

However, the St. Regis sets their own expectations.  A luxury experience.  Impeccable service. So when they fall short, I am not sure they should get a pass.

The room was lovely, giant by NYC standards. The turndown service  and butler service are among the best in the industry.  These far exceed what you will experience at a comparable Ritz or Four Season.

The service and dining left so much to be desired.  For example, I had confirmed an early check-in the day prior.  When we arrived, no room available.  The interaction with the front desk staff was terse, so much so, that upon walking away my daughter whispered that lady was such a Karen!  Hours later, we inquired if the room was ready by chat and by phone.  No one answered the chat.  No one answered the phone!  The phone rang in an endless loop before disconnecting.  This happened multiple times.  Finally, an hour after first trying to connect with them, someone answered that our room was ready!  Great joy but no one had contacted us as promised (contact info left with the front desk) so by that time we were across town.

The dining!  We ordered private dining twice and both experiences were on a TGIFridays level for food.  The exception: the shrimp cocktail.  WORTH IT. Beyond that, both times, items were forgotten and had to be brought later.  The french fries were unsalted (maybe the St. Regis cares deeply about my blood pressure) and bland.  Hear me when I say the lobster roll was the worst lobster roll on earth.  I struggle to describe the taste and texture of it but it was so disgusting.  If you have an enemy staying at the St. Regis order them the lobster roll, disgust guaranteed. Then breakfast...ugh.  The prices were out of control but that is expected.  The worst thing is I paid $36 for a cold Lender's bagel.  Surely the St. Regis could source better bagels in NYC!  Instead, you get a defrosted grocery store bagel.  Also, the pancakes...yikes.  

Were my expectations high?  Yes!  It's the St. Regis!  It is a lovely place to stay but don't expect perfection.

title: Mini Girl's Trip During Holiday Break
text:
Worst visit to the St. Regis New York.

Visited the city with my 2 girls during the Christmas holiday break from work -- Dec 27th -- 29th.  Only had a short period of time to spare and wanted to make the most of it.
Booked the King suite through my Marriott account.  Received an email on the 26th for early checkin, so I did.
Arrived at the St. Regis after long travel, at 7am on the 27th.  Made the front desk aware of this early arrival and was told as soon as a room was available, we would receive one.
Checked back with the front desk at 12pm to no avail.  Again at 2:30pm, while watching others checkin, I mean it's pretty crowded with other guests checking in at this point.
Our room still wasn't available, so we were told that every effort was made to try and get us in a room sooner but a guarantee for 4pm worst case scenario.

Checked back at 4:35 because the line was so long getting to the front desk.
Was told that my room wasn't available because of the request "if possible for queen beds, I will take it, but certainly not a must." But, we could upgrade to the Madison for additional $1000/night b/c it's usually $4k/night.
I stated that I would want the Madison but didn't agree with the additional charges due to my room not being ready anyway.
Again, checked in at 7am that morning for the first room available and at this point it's 5pm, we are exhausted from spending the time out on the streets while just wanting to take a shower, get settled in, change our clothes and go over our itinerary for our short stay.
During our wait, we decided to have lunch at the restaurant inside of the hotel. WORST EXPERIENCE.  I was not able to get the name of the hostess that sat us but she was racist.  Did not make eye contact.  Nor, were we even greeted.  Sat us down without taking our bags or coats, while hanging the coats of those around us.  On top of the lack of decency, she never advised our waiter of our seating.  We waited and waited until I could no longer take it.  We didn't even have water in our glasses nearing an hour after being seated.  Got the restaurants manager involved in this situation.

So, we did not receive our room until almost 8pm that evening.  Even when we received our room, the wanted to discuss charging us the up charge for the Madison suite.  I requested to speak to the manager.  I was advised that ORVILLE, at the guest counter, would be coming up to my room that evening to discuss waiving the up charge.  It NEVER happened.
Because of the restaurant issue, I was told that my meals would be complimentary -- that didn't happen.
Not one person throughout my stay called or came to my room to discuss charges.  It wasn't until my last day that they tried adding ALL of the fees that I was originally advised would be complimentary.  Once again, I had to spend the little bit of my vacation time discussing charged with the front desk, everyone acting oblivious over the mention of complimentary.  Them having to once again call out a manager for me to speak with.
Upon speaking with the manager while trying to leave, I was able to get the up charge waived, but my room service fees for dining they still charged.

This was the worst trip I have had at the St. Regis.  I usually travel in February with my white husband for my birthday.  It's a totally different experience when I am with my white husband.  I rarely get this alone time with my girls so I wanted to show them a good time.  I did not expect to encounter the racism and the feeling of being overlooked and degraded.

The only people that had any type of decency were the servicemen.  The bellmen Hector was great!  The butler Juan took the time to ask if we needed anything.  David the bellman was also great!  Jessie, a waiter in the restaurant, is the most pleasant and hospitable. Eddie, the driver of the complimentary car was social and AMAZING!

After finally getting settled in the room, our butler Flora was rude and called me a liar.  She said that she was just relaying a message from dining.  I was appalled by her behavior.  This was real upsetting.

St Regis, shame on you.  I really feel like I would not have had this experience if the color of my skin was white.

My daughter was able to spend one more day for vacation so I extended our stay.  I first checked with the Regis the morning of checkout to ask if we could stay another day in any room.  I was told "no."  I booked online about a mile away at the Marriott Residence Inn.  We received our room right away.  No wait time and the staff was extremely pleasant.

So, knowing we lost a whole day of our short stay waiting on our room, Marriott allows late checkout for Platinum members.  I was told that couldn't be honored.  I was rushed out of the room.  They even sent the bellman Hector up to grab our bags saying that we called him, knowing damn well, we did not make that call quite yet ...

I just don't know if I would like to continue my yearly routine of spending my bdays at the St Regis after this recent stay.

title: Put this hotel out to pasture.
text: Marriott ruins every luxury hotel they buy. This is a Marriott with a $2500 price tag. It has bad food, ok room, unfriendly checkin people and terrible service. Go to the Four Seasons. They are always consistent.

title: Special place where memories are made
text:
This was our first stay at a St. Regis and it was a terrific one. All the staffs were welcoming and warm, especially William (luggage), Franciesly, Julissa (front desk), and John (Butler). We’re not flashy people and we felt well respected and welcomed. For example, we were upfront about not having stayed at a St Regis before, and the front desk and the butler gave us a detailed overview of all the perks we were entitled for. Room service was impeccable every day, and so was breakfast. There were a few insignificant hiccups because of the holiday rush, but the hotel fixed them quickly every time. As Bonvoy Titanium members, we also received perks such as free breakfast (you have the option to have it delivered to your room for a small fee). All the services made our trip extra special. Thank you, St. Regis NYC!

A few things the hotel could improve:
1. The side of our bathrobes, although clean, were a little coarse (like old towels)
2. The slippers were tiny (I’m a male 9 and my feet could barely fit)
3. The Bose speakers do not support Bluetooth or lightning (iOS 16), only FM radio
4. For quick requests, it would have been great if guests could leave the butler a message (vs waiting for a call back)

title: A 5th Avenue Beaux  Arts Landmark Hotel.
text:
An iconic Big Apple landmark hotel, the St. Regis New York, is located prestigiously just off  5th Avenue in downtown Manhattan. The hotel is a hop-skip-and-a -jump from Central Park, Columbus Circle, the Met and others as well a being in the area that defines world class shopping.

I was delighted in my Superior room with king bed, leather bed headboard with decorative canopy, and 12 foot ceilings. The decor was a melange of old New York glamour and European influence with Art Deco flourishes, striped wallpaper, velvet sofa, Louis XVI antiques and a work desk. Crown moldings, elaborate chandeliers and large artistic photographs added a classy aspect to the atmosphere. The bathroom was marbleized with dual vanities, tub , rain shower and was outfitted with an all encompassing lighted mirror.

Exceptional dining is to be found in the Astor Court, the signature St. Regis restaurant which serves up international cuisine and is open for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Expect menu classics such as burrata and heirloom tomatoes or a simple grilled selection of meat & fish. My favorites included: French Onion Soup and the Spicy Shrimp Arrabbiata. The renowned King Cole Bar (which gave birth to the 1st Bloody Mary) was my addictive haunt. I would have been remiss if I would not have ordered at least one of those signature St. Regis Bloody Mary's.

I benefited from exceptional service, all with a smile and white gloves. Although not amenity rich, the hotel sported a modern state-of-the-art fitness center with everything I needed to maintain my gym regime as well as a majestic rooftop ballroom with panoramic Manhattan vistas, which I did not ballroom dance in.

If you prefer a hotel with a Gilded Age architecture located in one of the sweetest Manhattan spots...........then try the..................St. Regis New York.............................
........A 5th Avenue Beaux Arts Landmark Hotel.

title: Not so great
text:
Arrived 3 days ago for a 7 night stay in a 2 bedroom suite. The suite is amazing, unbeatable address but this is the first time in my life that I can’t have a drink at my hotel’s bar. There is a 30-60 minute line to go into the bar, this is beyond ridiculous for hotel guests. Im paying over $5k per night and have to go next door to the Peninsula for drinks !! 
If management reads this and is interested in repeat guests contact me.

title: Awesome Experience
text: This is a fantastic hotel! We came to this particular location to see it decorated for the holidays and it did not disappoint. Beautiful hotel, friendly staff, excellent food. To experience the St. Regis New York is a special treat. We loved our breakfast, and Muhammad in the Astor Court was kind, personable and extremely attentive. After bringing an annoyance with another guest (no fault of the hotel), George the front desk manager handled the situation extremely professionally. Would recommend this hotel to anyone looking to experience the height of luxury.

title: Lovely hotel
text: Beautiful hotel with excellent customer service and extras included. Beds were a little firm for our taste but the lines and pillows were quality. We were on the 18 floor at the end of the hall. The room was quiet and comfortable. Recommend for all types of travelers.

title: A Courtyard Marriott with Louis XIV furniture
text:
I should clarify before I begin that I very rarely leave reviews on TripAdvisor. It is usually to either praise exceptional service or make others aware of unexpectedly poor experiences.

The bottom line is this hotel is fine, but it is not a 5-star property in many ways, several of which I shall describe chronologically. 

On arrival at the hotel in the evening at around 9:45 pm, there were no staff to be seen. Most 5-star properties in New York are famous for the ever-present doormen and bellboys to help with luggage and settling in. This left us with five large bags on the sidewalk with no one to assist. Eventually, someone appeared and was able to get a bellboy to assist. Similarly, on entering the reception it was deserted until a member of staff appeared from a nearby office. 

Immediately upon check-in, I asked what my options were if I wanted to extend my checkout time to 6 pm the following day and that if necessary I would pay any fees/extra rates. Now, this is where I was reminded that I was not staying in a real 5-star hotel, but actually just a shinier Marriott. I was told that I could receive a late checkout at 2 pm, or pay a half-day rate to get a check-out at 4 pm, but to check out at 6 pm I would need to pay an entire extra night. As far as I could tell, a half-day normally means more than an additional two hours, but I said that was fine and I would pay for an extra night.

The receptionist at this point then disappeared into the office and returned to say that my room had been upgraded to a $10,000-a-night suite but I would have to leave at 2 pm. I explained I did not want an upgrade, but just a late checkout, even if it meant paying. She disappeared once more into the office and returned. She explained her manager was happy for me to leave at 6 pm the next day free of charge, but I would have to take a smaller room. I once again explained I did not mind the cost, I just wanted to check out at 6 pm. She disappeared for a third time into the office and came back to inform me that I could stay till 6 pm by paying for an extra night, but that I would need to make the booking online myself and then let them know, and that we would be able to stay in the $10,000 a night suite (that I didn't ask for at any point) the entire time at the cost of my original booking. Eventually, this was resolved, with what I asked for all along, which was an additional night on my booking which I was happy to pay for.

What I found strangest about this entire experience, was that while the receptionist disappeared so many times to see her manager, the manager himself did not come out to speak to us  – even though, awkwardly, I could see him at his desk through the door each time she went away. Again, this is extremely unusual behaviour for a 5-star hotel, and it would not have been difficult for him to come and work through it directly and personally. The entire experience simply reminded me this is a property in a very large corporate chain.

The suite itself was fine – I would, however, be extremely disappointed if I was paying $10,000 a night as the receptionist said its rate was. The decor is confusing, with suede curtains and electric blinds that go up and down until they eventually fall. There is also a large decorative mirror balanced on the floor leaning against a wall.

Having been travelling all day, we ordered room service. The food took longer than expected, for which the waiter apologised without prompting, but it was also cold. Similarly, a couple of requested substitutions were ignored and other items were forgotten. 

Other minor quibbles include a lack of overnight laundry, again unusual among fellow five-star properties across the US and worldwide. 

I realise it appears I am playing one of the world's smallest violins to criticise the service of a hotel that costs thousands of dollars a night, but that is precisely the point of this review. For those who enjoy five-star hotels, or are using their points to stay in one, be aware that it is not what you should expect or deserve. 

I would instead recommend a property like the Four Seasons, the Peninsula, or the Rosewood Group.

title: Great stay!
text:
We had a great stay at this beautiful and surprisingly quiet hotel in midtown. We stayed 5 nights in an Astor suite facing 55th street and it was lovely. The blackout curtains drowned out the light and noise from busy midtown and we slept like a dream. 

Admittedly we booked a more basic room, used suite nights to upgrade to an enhanced room, and then were given a complimentary upgrade based on our Ambassador status. This obviously makes a difference to us because we did not pay full price, but we would return nonetheless. 

As part of being elite status you can have $135 breakfast credit in your room or $115 at the restaurant. We did mostly room breakfasts. I recommend ordering the night before. Each time the staff was prompt and friendly and if they forgot anything they were quick to remedy the situation. 

We had two items pressed in the morning and they were back in our room later that day. 

The room was huge and we had two bathrooms. We didn't spend much time in the hotel as we were there on business, but each time we came back to our room it was clean. The TV's are comically small given that it's the year 2022, but it certainly adds to the charm. 

One night we had dinner at the bar and it was delicious (and obviously expensive). I'll say the presence of escorts is a little on the nose, but they didn't bother us. 

Our only complaint is that the bar closes at 11pm. After a broadway show on friday night we hurried back hoping to grab a drink before it closed but they wouldn't let us in. I understand you have set hours and it's challenging to staff your hotels, but it's a little strange to be an internationally acclaimed hotel that closes its only bar at 11pm on a weekend night. There was no shortage of guests who wanted to be there; while we were turned away so were two other couples within seconds of us. 

This wasn't unique to the St. Regis; the Polo Bar, Peninsula hotel, Whitby, plaza, the ritz, all close their bars between 10-11pm even on friday and saturday nights. It really makes you question if this is still the city that never sleeps!

title: Overpriced, tired and trading on an undeserved ‘luxury’ reputation
text:
I have thought long and hard about leaving a review for this hotel but it had such a disruptive impact on my recent break that I thought I had to.  I'll also be writing to Marriott Bonvoy to express my concerns.

Checked into St Regis for a long anticipated five night stay with my wife.   We had very high expectations of the hotel. 

As a Gold Marriott member we paid for the room with Bonvoy points (around 495000 points or the equivalent of $1700 per night) After a long flight from London we arrived in the hotel around 10:30pm. We were told that no upgrades were available to our room as the hotel was "fully booked". As a gold member I would normally get these subject to availability - I don't expect them (however I was told  exactly the same thing back in 2018 when I last stayed at the property).  

On entering the room we discovered one very small window (overlooking a dirty concrete void - see photo) in a room that had clearly seen better days - with very tired scarlet decor.  It was also apparent that the room was next to the main elevator shaft.   We like a tub in our bathroom so were disappointed to only find a shower.

We went down to the front desk and asked to be moved to a room with at least one usable window and a bathtub, and away from lift noise.  We were informed that the hotel was fully booked and nothing was available for least 3 days  - however the duty manager at the time told us we could avail of food and drinks in the restaurant and bar (this was at around 11pm).  

We were really jet lagged but thought a drink might take the edge off our disappointment.  Of course when we tried to go to the bar it was closed (as was the restaurant).  What kind of offer is that?  

Deeply unhappy now we went back to the room to find that the room safe was non-functional and toiletries in the bathroom had been used.  These were the last straws and we rebooked another hotel that evening for the rest of the stay.  

The following morning we spoke to hotel management whilst checking out who apologized and (too late) offered us an alternative room.  Suddenly something had become available !

We were not refunded our points balance for the night we stayed but were given a credit back of 25,000 points which, given that some people have obtained twice as much for poor butler service or cold beverages seems derisory.

This experience completely ruined the first part of our stay.  The hotel fell far behind the standards I would expect of such a property.  

I have to also mention that they ought to be honest upfront and say that they will not upgrade under any circumstances.  I would not have a problem with that at all.    

The King Cole bar and its location are the only redeeming features of this hotel - there are far better value properties in the city.

title: Excellent
text: This hotel remains as reliable and luxurious as ever. My favourite in New York and always a pleasure to return. The staff are always extremely polite and helpful. Hotel being on 5th and 55th is perfectly located

title: Iconic Stay at an Iconic Hotel
text: Celebrated our anniversary at this wonderful hotel! Stayed in the 5th Ave corner suite. It was truly an incredible time.  Everything from the butler service, quiet bedroom, beautiful decor, and iconic bar were perfection!

title: A high end hotel with all imaginable service
text:
We stayed here a couple of nights, this is a old style hotel with a service that corresponds to a hotel in this class. There is absolutely nothing to complain about. The rooms a spacious and clean, the beds are very comfortable. The serve of course breakfast but we didn't eat any breakfast at the hotel, we took one of several places that serve breakfast in the neighborhood.  

This is maybe not a hotel for people with a tight budget, but its worth the money and it´s location is perfect.

title: St. Regis is TOP TIER
text:
Beautiful hotel! This hotel is located conveniently near top attractions like central park, Rockefeller centre and many more.

The check in process was smooth. There was an issue with the room category booked, however we were able to resolve things quickly and Vince was very helpful. The valet team was great out front. They were hard to notice at first considering there were a million parked cars out front, but thats normal for nyc.

The wifi was great at this location. The butler service was excellent. We had Delores and Aminah help us out during out stay. Special thanks to Delores!

The staff onsite are incredibly pleasant and helpful. Really was giving 5 star hotel and the regal architecture was beautifully maintained. Most of the rooms carrying the same elements as well.

Fridges fully stocked and room service menu was excellent. Highly recommend getting the morning coffee to your room, it’s to die for.

title: Ticks the boxes
text: We very much enjoyed the St Regis. The staff are friendly, accommodating, but also not overtly formal - which we like. The room was very large and quiet (no view) which for us is a big plus. The location worked very well for us. A few small issues to nitpick on: room service breakfast pretty basic and could be better presented; no kettle.

title: Impeccable Service and Accommodations
text: The St. Regis New York ticks all of the boxes - location, service and luxury accommodations.  The front desk greeting was warm and inviting, the room was luxurious and comfortable, housekeeping was excellent and staff throughout the hotel could not have been lovelier.  The hotel is worth every penny.  You will not be disappointed!

title: Stay away !!!!
text:
The property is pretty and well located, and the good part ends here.

Issues with the hotel:

1. Most of the hotel staff are very rude and unwilling to assist with anything. Very LOW service level for a 5 star hotel. 

2. The final check out bill always has mistakes. In my last stay in June, i was over charged 700 usd and reimbursed only after i contacted the hotel. I was even charged for “butler service” of tea and coffee , which is provided free of charge. When contacting Omar, the guest services manager, he updated me that he is in a vacation and will reimburse upon his return. My PA had to call and email multiple times to make sure this was done. During this stay- same story. Multiple mistakes in the bill. First time i thought its an innocent mistake, this time i am not so sure. 

3. I have left sunglasses that are of sentimental value for me in the hotel’s restaurant and requested the restaurant manager to look at the cameras facing the table to find out who took it. The security came and said they have no access to it till a day after my checkout , and that anyway they wont bother checking for an item of sentimental value.

I asked to speak to Melanie, hotel director of operations , and was said she js busy and wont talk to me . When I insisted, she came and I told her about the unpleasant events. She did not even apologize or offered any sort of compensation.

Omar (guest relations) was even worst. He said that if i have problems with the hotel , i shouldn't stay there . Like how dared i to complain for charges that were not even mine ? (based on the fact that they did 700 usd mistake in my bill last time and others this time).

 Instead of apologizing for multiple mistakes and low level of service he actually blamed the client.

If i could give this hotel ZERO points i would.

The hotel is unpleased, unaccommodating, with a 1 star service level

NOT recommended!!!

title: Top hotel in NYC
text: Excellent location right on 5th Ave. Each room has butler service . Room was a good size with a beautiful bathroom . Staff was very nice especially the concierge Kevin & from desk person Vincent . We would definitely stay here again.  Lots of great restaurants nearby.

title: Service needs work
text:
Stayed a couple of nights this summer in a suite. The room itself was beautiful, location is impeccable, etc. but ultimately disappointing due to multitude of service mistakes that should not be happening at a hotel of this price range. To summarize: 

1. I pre-arranged with the concierge to have fresh flowers in the room upon check in. Our room was not ready when we initially arrived, and the front desk separately confirmed that the flowers would be in the room once it was ready. A few hours later we were informed that the room was ready and picked up our keys. The flowers were not in the room and did not arrive for several hours. 

2. Our butler never came by to introduce himself/herself as is customary (and as the front desk indicated would happen) 

3. We ended up arriving at the room at around 3pm. The room was already set up in turn down service mode (towel, slippers, water by the bed). We had a rest and then went out for dinner +  a show and came back around midnight. The room was in the same condition as we left it with the bed unmade. When I talked to a service manager about this, it was indicated that because we already received turndown service that day (before check-in), the housekeeping team does not go back into the room. 

4. The next day I called for the butler to press my suit and return it in the afternoon by a certain time. I was assured this would be done. 30 minutes past the time I set there was no suit and I had to call down again to have the suit brought up. Apparently the previous butler's shift was over and never communicated to the new butler that my suit was to be delivered by a certain time. 

5. I talked to a service manager about these issues and was offered 50k Bonvoy points as compensation. I accepted as none of these issues were major. However, these points still have not been deposited in my account, now 2 months after my stay. 

The hotel itself is beautiful and timeless. None of the above issues are a dealbreaker in and of themselves, but when a hotel is charging the rates that the NY St Regis is, a certain level of quality and consistency should be expected. As I experienced it, the service does not match the quality of the hotel.

title: Perfect Stay!
text: Love the hotel, friendly staff and great location. This is the hotel to stay when you are in the big Apple without a doubt. Everything is close by, plus room service is always the best after a long day of shopping on Fifth Avenue. If you stay here always ask for the higher floor, you will love the views.

title: Luxurious quick overnight stay
text:
Stayed here overnight in July. The room was enormous and spotless (we did not feel like you were in NYC). All the furnishings were top notch and every room has a butler.  We only called the butler once but when they came it was very fast and they were very attentive. 

If you are looking for a nightlife/bar experience the bar closes at 11-11:30 so this is not the right place for you, just don't stay in Midtown. 

Certainly would stay here again!

title: Service compensated for food
text: I recently had brunch at the Astor Room.  The omelet was rubbery and the fillings were almost nonexistent.   Very disappointing...however, the service was excellent and the atmosphere and history of the hotel is charming.

title: Perfection
text:
Just completed an amazing two night stay at the St. Regis.  
Location is great.  Close to the shops on 5th, walking distance to Central Park and easy to get to Broadway theatres.
If you like modern hotels - this is not the hotel for you.  If you like old school luxury hotels, then you will be very pleased.  The rooms are stunning.  The wallpaper and the marble and the gold accents are simply stunning.  The bathtubs (and there were two in our suite!) are very comfortable.  I never wanted to leave our suite. 
The two standout staff members are Christina at the Front Desk and Dolores, our butler.  Dolores has been with the St. Regis for 28 years and is superb.  She helped with pressing our clothes, bringing us coffee/tea in the morning, coordinating with bell desk and housekeeping and pretty much anything else you would request.  
Breakfast is included if you are an Elite Bonvoy member (platinum and above) up to $135 credit for two people either at Astor Court or room service.  This was a great value.  
Room service was surprisingly fast.  Never longer than half an hour.
My only complaint about this hotel is that it has ruined all other hotels for me, because nothing else can possibly compare to the NY St. Regis! 
The hotel is pricey, but it was worth every penny for our special occasion.  
I’m already thinking about a return visit next time we have something to celebrate!

title: Nice location for shopping, needs updating
text:
This was our second time staying at the St. Regis NY in many years.  The positives are:

1) Great location especially if you are here for shopping. At the corner of 5th and 55th, you're right in the poshest area of 5th Avenue and a few blocks from Central Park to the north and St. Patrick's / Rockefeller Center to the south.
2) The usual high standard of St. Regis service - prompt, polite and erring on the side of over-delivering

The negatives:
1) As a relatively low and older building in NYC, it's difficult to get any kind of view, even when paying up for a premium outer room.
2) The public areas and rooms are feeling increasingly dated - needs renovation and brightening up.  This was a disappointment since our last stay.
3) The great shopping location can be a nightmare in terms of traffic, which was often at a standstill in front of the hotel - we typically walked a few blocks away to get a taxi or Uber

We generally like St. Regis hotels but at this price range this wouldn't be our first choice in this general area of Manhattan.

title: Horrible Hotel Experience - No Sleep
text: Our family arrived to the Saint Regis today. We checked into the room this afternoon. Once my daughter and husband unpacked and began relaxing we heard loud music coming from nearby. We called down multiple times complaining both this afternoon and yet again tonight. No one hears the music other than us, so they say. Tonight 12 am July 30th Music is blasting in our ears blasting through our head board & pillows. We are staying in a junior suite on the 14th floor. Probably close to thousand for one night of a terrible headache. Upon our arrival into the room which was 1pm we heard loud music repeating on the same loop. It’s too late to switch rooms our daughter is asleep. You want us to move? That’s unfair at 12:30 am. Shame on the persons having a party, shame on the hotel management on not resolving this problem. I do not recommend. When I checked with my daughter, I have my drivers license, the front desk blonde women, informed me that  needed a phone call from my husband would need to come meet at the front desk or make a phone call proving my husband and I are both staying the room. When the front desk women met my husband she said I do see now there is a Mrs..How awful between the first moments checking in trying to reach a bathroom to the music blasting and my migraine keeping me awake. I do think this hotel deserves zero stars. We won’t go back here to the St. Regis NYC.

title: Nice experience in summer
text:
I was debating between 4 and 5 - going with 5 due to the FHR upgrade from base room to Astor suite after we indicated we were ok waiting for a room till 430 (didn’t get a callback but when I called a room was available - app showed Madison but in the end got an Astor). 
Property was nice, food exceptional (we have curry often enough and while $66 is almost highway robbery, the curry here was exceptional, not sure how they made it but we ordered it twice).

We had an incident involving room service coming into the wrong room at 1am but got a few fruit bowls the next day to compensate. Minor issues included having 5 butlers over the course of a 2 night stay and not having clarity on food pricing (there were room delivery and set up charges for breakfast, which along with some errors took our bill to $182 vs the $100 that we calculated - eventually it was waived after spending 10 min at checkout to reconcile but that was not ideal). Also ordering shower items via the app didn’t work well - both times it wasn’t delivered although after calling they did deliver. Laundry service was excellent and so was housekeeping.  Overall we had a great experience.

title: Disappointing Stay for a 5 Star Hotel
text:
We recently completed staying at the St Regis for our honeymoon in NYC and after considering all aspects, it was a very poor experience considering the level of the St. Regis prides itself of having. It’s the very beginning of our trip and we expected a lot when we booked this. 

The most frustrating issue was the front desk agent Jonathan failing to tell us about the daily destination credit, but instead of just informing us, he gaslighted us by saying we forgot because he has worked here for so long. I can absolutely assure you that is not the case since we arrived at the Hotel at 2PM, our room was not ready until 4:30PM and if you told me I had a credit to the bar… that’s the first place I’m going! 

After that, we had other issues:
1) Paging the butler, but no one showed up or called back. No greeting by the butler at all. Some reviews say they unpack your clothes? 
2) No effort to make our stay above and beyond, we told Jonathan it was our honeymoon and zero recognition of that. For a 5 star resort, even a congratulation note would be nice. Here, no effort to do anything. Even more frustrating he could’ve just sent us to the bar to use our credit…. 
3) This one looking back just seems like a money grab so it’s frustrating… as I said earlier we showed up at 2PM but was told our room wasn’t ready until 4PM. We didn’t get a call until late so we returned at 6:30PM. To my surprise our bags weren’t brought up to our room. We had to call to get them to bring it up… just so we can tip the person. I already tipped when we came in, this just seems petty to me. If we handed in the slip during check in, and they know which bags are ours, why wouldn’t the bags be in our room already?

Further, since my wife answered the door she didn’t notice one of the bags were missing. I had to go downstairs to the luggage room and find my bag there. When I got there, there were cockroaches. What kind of 5 star resort is this?? 

I will say Franciely took great care of us. But Jonathan’s attitude and gaslighting along with each department’s failure to deliver (luggage/doorman/etc.) made this resort akin to a motel 6 with the cockroaches running around our luggage.

title: Super happy ⭐️
text: We stayed for 3  days at the ST.Regis hotel NYC after we flew  back from morocco we had a wonderful experience the staff are very welcoming and the rooms were  very  clean we ordered room service (breakfast)  it was well prepared and delicious special thanks to the concierge team ( Nourdine . Mustapha & Kevin ) for getting us transportation back-and-forth from the Hotel to Airport and always checking on us  and a special thanks for the bellman team  👍🏻👍🏻👍🏻👍🏻👍🏻 we are definitely coming back

title: Perfection
text:
First time stay at The St. Regis and it exceeded my expectations. 

Exceptional hotel and outstanding customer service. Linens were heaven, the room was immaculate, and our butler Tamara Nisonava was excellent and spoiled us. Everything about this hotel was exceptional.

title: 5 star on the outside NOT the inside
text:
This hotel has the underpinnings of a five star hotel without the ‘real stuff’.

The lobby, location and amenities are first rate.

However to be told by the bellman  to just wait to check in because no one is at the front desk for several minutes  is unacceptable.. For the doorman not to even move to open the Uber door or offer to take your bag but rather just stand on the sidelines again is unacceptable. To pay 5 star rates and have a bathroom that measures 8x8 doesn’t work for me either. The shower was 3x3 and for someone larger would probably be a real problem.

title: Truly a luxurious experience
text:
We stayed at the st Regis to celebrate my husbands milestone birthday. Unlike any other hotel in NYC this one comes with a butler. 
Check in was super smooth we got a room on a higher floor as requested with views! Some views 

Our butler was superb!! She made sure we felt comfortable. We requested for our coffee to be served immediately instead of in the morning and she was happy to oblige.

We could’ve gotten our garments pressed but we skipped. There’s also a car that can take you 10 blocks from the hotel but we had gotten our car with us (valet with in and our privileges) so we didn’t use their car.

The breakfast next day at the Astor court was also amazing!! The hotel is a piece of history still standing talk in the middle of Nyc. If you explore the hotel areas and look for details you will find them. It’s modern very modern yet retains the original charm. 

Our only complaint was the nuts and food in the room was all expired. We wanted to munch on something with our coffee but were sad to discover most of the snacks in our room were expired. Management should check these and change time to time. Oh did I mention how spotless the bathroom was?! Yes I’m one of those that loves her bathroom to be spotless.

title: Historic hotel - great butler service
text:
Stayed here for a quick one night stay - first time here. 

Check in was smooth - and I was extremely delighted to find out that they upgraded me to a deluxe one bedroom suite. The suite was beautifully appointed - the only small complaint would be that the TV (especially the one in the living room) was horribly small - the viewing distance is probably wrong and they can do with a much lager screen for both the living and bedrooms. 

Special mention to my butler Dolores, whom has been a long timer at the Property and attended some of my last minute request swiftly and efficient - very much appreciated. 

This is not a hotel for the views (except perhaps some of the Central Park facing 5* hotels) but the location and staff were unbeatable - will look to return!

title: Spectacular experience for our anniversary
text:
We stayed for two nights at the St. Regis Hotel in midtown Manhattan.  This is an ultra luxury hotel that delivers a spectacular experience.

The review needs to start by pointing out rooms start at about $900 a night.  That is before tax and the $50/day resort fee.  

What do you get for your money?  Why is it worth it?  Every room comes with butler service.  There is a uniformed butler who shows you around your room.  They will unpack your luggage and put things into various drawers.  They will press two garments per day free of charge.  They will bring coffee to your room upon request.  The coffee comes in a French press and it is spectacular.  Your but.er is also your “go to” person when you need to get things done.  We wanted reserved seats in the hotel bar.  Done.  We wanted the New York Times every day.  Done.

The St. Regis hotel has house cars.  They function as private taxis for guests.  Their Rolls Royce was in for service.  The cars we rode in were current model Mercedes S Class models.

We have status in the Marriott Bonvoy rewards program.  Our Titanium status gets us a room upgrade when available.  We also had a few upgrade certificates as part of the titanium perks.  As a result, we found ourselves in a Madison Suite, a one bedroom suite with two marble bathrooms.  FYI:  The Madison Suite is not named after James Madison, it’s one of the suites overlooking Madison Avenue.   There are even grander suites then the one we got!

The rooms are large, regardless of what you book.  One of the features of the hotel is the silk wall coverings.  I noticed there were no paintings or artwork in our room, then realized the huge fabric panels are the artwork.  The bedroom had a tv.  The living room had a tv.  Both bathrooms had TVs built into the mirror over the sink.  There are plenty of TVs!

I had the best night’s sleep in a long time!  The bed is spectacular.  There is a turndown service in the evening.  The room was incredibly quiet.  The rooms also have crystal chandeliers, another hallmark of the hotel.

We had breakfast in the Astor Dining Room, the hotel restaurant.  Breakfast is a perk that comes with the Bonvoy level.  You are allowed the American breakfast, which is ideal.  It includes juice, coffee, eggs, potatoes, breakfast meat and choice of breads.  The regular price for breakfast is $42 per person before tax and tip.  That Marriott perk is valuable.

We were celebrating out 40th wedding anniversary.  We booked our room with Bonvoy rewards points.  It cost a lot of points, but for celebrating our anniversary. It was worth it..

title: Iconic hotel struggling with staffing/service levels
text:
Our first impressions of this iconic hotel were not good. The queue to check in was horrendous. We were offered a bottle of water whilst we waited 20 mins only to be told that the check-in time of 4pm was being strictly enforced. When we came back an hour later, we had to endure another longish wait but to their credit we were upgraded to wonderful 1-bedroom Astor suite.

The suite was excellent with all mod cons including a TV in the bathroom, Bose music player and mood lighting. But, for over $1k per night, there was no complimentary welcome drink, fruit basket, etc. 

We were not offered much in the way of service throughout our stay due to post pandemic staffing issues. Our butler did make contact once and did provide a complimentary tray of coffee in the morning on request (there’s no tea or coffee facilities in the room but you can get it delivered free before noon). 

There's no pool at the hotel. The gym is small but functional and quite busy in the mornings.

Breakfast was cooked to order. As we had Elite status, the American Breakfast at $46 each was complimentary. However, the waiters were quite flexible and allowed us to swap out the standard breakfast for other items on the menu for no extra charge. The pancakes were excellent as was the coffee. 

We tried the iconic King Cole bar, which was smaller and cosier than expected but very busy. The cocktails were quite good in the main although the signature red snapper cocktail was way too strong. The free snacks - wasabi peas and Bombay crackers - were dismal…good quality nuts would be a far better accompaniment. 

All things considered, we enjoyed our stay here but would have like to give it a try when staffing and service levels are back to normal.

title: Full Disclosure
text: Wonderful property. One interesting point is that on top of the quoted fee, there’s a fee described as Resort Fee. It’s $50. So add that your budget. It was explained to me that high end hotels do it so the St. Regis did it as well. It is not a tax so one can’t blame the city of NY. It’s an additional fee added by the St. Regis because they can.

title: Moderate Service Improvements Would Help for StR Level
text:
I am aware that service standards in NYC are not what they are in Asia or in the Middle East so I try to judge by local standards, but nonetheless based on my stay at StR NYC I am not sure this StR was quite on par with the brand.    

Our stay did not start on the right foot - first off there was no pre-arrival e-mail which would be an easy thing to do, then check-in was a bit chaotic because they chose 7pm as the appropriate time to vacuum the (small) reception area and I could barely hear the receptionist speaking to me from behind a glass wall. I suspect that in-room check-in is rare in NYC luxury hotels (unlike elsewhere in the world) but in those circumstances if there ever was a time where it would have been useful, this would be it. There was nobody to accompany us to our room after check-in either, and no mention of the butler - if I was not familiar with the brand I would have no idea there was supposed to be one. I am guessing they might be short staffed relative to guest count which is easier to accept for a select service hotel than a StR. 

At this hotel the Suite Night Awards do not go higher than Grand Luxe which is not a suite so the "S" part of SNA is questionable consequently I did not use an SNA but ended up being upgraded to that room type anyway.

The best feature was that the room had excellent soundproofing from outside and within, unlike some newer hotels where we can hear traffic noise (especially in NYC) and people in the hallway.  However the room had some issues due to the building being old, for example we partially lost power twice during the stay and the cord for the blinds broke; consequently one day we did not have day light and after they fixed it was only temporary because the problem was simply reversed: we could not move them back down anymore with the cable still hanging on the floor. 

Since our check-in process was not the most thorough, the only discussion about breakfast was that we could order the American breakfast as the Platinum (or above) benefit but no mention of potential flexibility to order anything else (including something cheaper on the menu).  The American breakfast was 46 USD per person so for a couple it was close to 100 USD value – the issue is not that I believe the credit was stingy, the issue is more about offering alternatives and proactively mentioning it to guests upon check-in.  What stood out favorably was the ability to have breakfast as room service instead of limiting it to the restaurant.

Service was not stellar overall due to some issues mentioned above but in their defense some aspects were good.  For example any time I made a request in the chat (Marriott app) they were very responsive and housekeeping was done at the time we requested, and was done noticeably well compared to most other hotels.  I shipped some packages to the hotel before my arrival and they were left in our room upon arrival so the service on point in that regard as well, however they charged 11 USD per parcel which was not mentioned ahead of time.  Charging for this service seems more suitable for select service hotels than a St.Regis but it was a minor issue in the grand scheme of things.  

I did not intend to "complain" since none of our issues were terrible and the most important is that we could sleep well. However by coincidence during our stay I e-mailed the Marriott Ambassador service for a request completely unrelated to StR NYC and they happened to ask me how my check-in went at StR. I never had a request for comments about the check-in process specifically so I thought it was odd, anyway I took the opportunity to point out some areas of improvement in my humble opinion. The ambassador agent forwarded my e-mail to the hotel and after I checked out a manager called to thank me for my feedback, we discussed some things which could have gone better. I appreciated that someone followed up so it improved my perception of the hotel and I could give them another chance later.

To conclude on service, one luxury aspect not found in many other hotels is the hotel car service within 10 blocks for guest use which is a feature I hope they will retain.

Overall our stay was mixed with various potential areas of improvement but at least the ending was satisfactory and the hotel showed they were eager to listen and improve which keeps the door open for me to return, unlike some hotels which are tone deaf and clearly leave customer feedback way down their list of priorities.

title: Beware the depressing “Grand Luxe” suite
text: Service level is as expected for this tier of hotel. Was upgraded to a “Grand Luxe” room, but it’s a small suite at what appears to be a basement level - depressing even for NYC. I would have declined the upgrade if knew we’d have to leave the hotel to see sunlight. See photos.

title: Denied a cancellation due to Covid
text: I am sure the hotel is wonderful. After booking this hotel, our family got Covid and was unable to travel. You would think that would be an acceptable reason for cancelling a trip. However, the manager, Suzanne, said we could not cancel the trip and instead stuck us with a $1,500 bill. As a long time Marriott points user, this is pretty disappointing.

title: My favorite in Manhattan: another incredible Ambassador stay and amazing suite upgrade
text:
My 5 night stay last week at the St Regis New York to celebrate my mother’s 75th birthday was absolutely fantastic. 
#stregis #newyorkcity #stregisnewyork #suiteupgrades #astorsuite #grandluxeroom #billsalltimefavorites 

Despite the hotel being sold out for 3 of my 5 nights, I was upgraded as an Ambassador guest a day before arrival to an Astor Suite. My mother’s room also was upgraded to a Grand Luxe room. I tipped the front desk well at the end. FWIW those upgrades together were worth over $8K. Not bad for a $20K investment for Ambassador status.
#AmbassadorStatusMatters 
#AmbassadorStatusMattersMoreAtNicerHotels 
#AmbassadorStatusInstTheSameAsTitanium

This all was on top of the hotel GM honoring my insanely good BRG rate from my 2020 intended stay that was canceled due to covid by extending a very generous comparable rate for both rooms for this stay. FWIW, that generosity saved me almost $5K alone. 

My Ambassador pre-arrival checklist items were all handled. The suite was pre-cooled to 65 F. I asked the engineer to cool it down further and it got as cold as 61 F. Heavenly. I also had four bottles of water provided every day by housekeeping (even when they forgot), and had a fan by the bed. Shades and blinds made for blackout as requested. My welcome amenity of chocolate covered strawberries was delicious; my mother got those as well as a bottle of Prosecco. 

The concierge team was as impressive as ever. Months and weeks before arrival, they helped get us bookings for 3* Le Bernardin, 1* Gramercy Tavern, 1* Marea, and The Grill. They also helped with several lunch recommendations — and for ordering flowers for my mother’s room at the last minute. I tipped them well at the end.

Housekeeping was very good. I never saw them, in fact. They did miss turndown the first night, but they got it every other night. They didn’t always close all the curtains in the suite, and they occasionally forgot to bring my extra water bottles, but they usually promptly made up for it. I tipped them well at the end.

Butler service was very good. Unpacking was a bit clumsier than usual IIRC, but I was still grateful for the service. Shoe shine and pressing were great. Morning coffee service was always fast and gracious, and they always were willing to bring me more if I needed anything. They were just as good for my mother. I tipped them well at the end.

The St Regis New York shower also remains my favorite in the world, with the best but softest water pressure I’ve ever enjoyed. It’s incredible. The shower room is small, but that soft water pressure is so addictive.

Food and beverage were extremely impressive. The elite status breakfast benefit is an impressive $135 credit for up to 2 persons per room, and I never hit it — whether via room service or at the Astor Court restaurant. I did room service breakfast for 3 of my mornings and Astor Court breakfast for the other 2. Room service was usually fast (less than 30 min) and with hot food, but one morning was a disaster where they obviously got it all wrong — and it took an hour and was only warm. They couldn’t have been more apologetic, but since it was free and so generous I didn’t worry more about it. 

The one oddity of room service was having two different servers on two different occasions opening my suite door without my answering it while bringing up some extra items. It was a bit disconcerting, and the F&B manager mentioned his surprise and that more training was necessary. Clearly, a newer F&B staff training issue.

I also had dinner one night with friends at Astor Court — and it was delicious. First time I’ve ever had dinner at the hotel, but it measured up. It’s no Lambs Club at the Chatwal Hotel, but it was still quite impressive. 

We also met my brother and sister-in-law at the King Cole Bar to surprise my mother for her birthday. George, who had worked with us during our 2018 Table 55 experience, recognized me as I walked in and totally took care of us. George has worked at the King Cole for 30 years; he is is an absolute gem. He even got us a reserved table for the following night. This remains one of my favorite hotel bars in NYC.

The doormen were fab. They got us the house car (now a Mercedes S) that I’d never used previously in order to pick up my mother from the train station. They also got us taxis and recs whenever we needed them and always offered a helping hand for my mother. I tipped them well each time.

Service overall was as impressive as I remember — which is particularly impressive knowing the staff supply issues and new training obviously endemic to all hotels. Staff throughout the hotel remembered us by name far more than I remember being common, more reminding me of an Aman stay.  Everyone was gracious and friendly and always eager to help.

Overall, it was a 9.5 out of 10 for me and my mother. It wasn’t perfect, but it was sublime. They made a few mistakes, but they totally took care of us in every way. The suite and my mother’s room both were incredibly comfortable. The hotel completely exudes New York with a sense of place unmatched by almost any of the other top luxury hotels. 

I can’t wait to return. Even as I don’t love New York. The St Regis New York delivers in spades. Definitely one of the best. Definitely my second favorite city hotel in the USA. And definitely still one of #billsalltimefavorites.

title: Great property, OK service
text:
I travel regularly and have stayed at a range of Marriott properties.

I was only here for one evening  to scout it out as a potential vacation spot for family. The building is stunning. My room was clean and comfortable - especially the bathroom. The food is OK but is very overpriced (think ~$60 for an average omelette), and I did get some snacks/drinks from the honor bar and can imagine those too will be overpriced.

I was mostly surprised by how unremarkable the service was. My room was ready late (about an hour and a half after the estimated time/after I checked in) and the hotel wouldn't accommodate any late checkout. I did get an upgrade for status, which was nice. I tried to order food in the evening via the Marriott app and ended up calling in the order after 30 minutes (nobody ever responded to the text order). The staff are friendly but the lack of attention to detail and basic accommodations is something that was a little disappointing for a Marriott luxury property.

Overall it's a beautiful property and maybe I had an off-night, but if you're looking for a luxe experience with great service, I'd recommend considering the nearby Ritz over this option.

title: More Minuses than pluses
text:
Great ambiance and clean.  The rooms are nice, not breathtaking but nice. 

I'm a Marriott Gold member.  I was told I had a free upgrade.  I did not get it.  I checked in the night before on the Bon Voy app and posted a check in time of 12pm.  Our room wasn't ready until 3:30pm.  That was with the front desk "expediting."  Although they removed the charges, I was billed over $200 for honor bar fees.  My wife and I took only two sodas.  The turn down service came, I told her it wasn't needed.  15 minutes later she came back and tried to reenter our room scaring the daylights out of my wife.  If you order room service you must tip or they start talking and won't leave.  The food was mediocre, at best, and way over priced.  And, if you're going to boast about Bloody Mary's please make them better than a local pub.  The staff in general are experts in extracting money from people.  Being a Gold member I'm supposed to get a late check out at 2pm.  Housekeeping came knocking at 11:30am.

Overall, I've paid a lot less for a lot more.  I found the entire experience to be average but the bill to be high end.  I was paid for the 55th Street location and the hotel's reputation.  Nothing more.

title: Rude, discriminatory staff towards Asians
text: I stayed at the St.Regis in May for my child’s graduation with my family. The location is very good and the rooms were amazing, but some of the staff seemed very discriminatory (even racist) towards Asians like myself. In the mornings when I went to breakfast with my family, the two hostess women would not welcome us and just stood there ignoring us, not doing their job. However, they treated their white customers very kindly and were very attentive. When they finally seated us, they always sit us in the corner on the counter tables even when other comfortable tables in the middle were always available. Their service was terrible too. They would ignore us, not take our order for over 20 minutes, take 20 minutes to bring a simple coffee with the excuse that they forgot, and our food took ridiculously long. Just looking around, they were clearly treating white people better. A stark difference in treatment between POC and whites. This happened everyday of our stay. There were some nice staff members but I cannot compliment them as that is the bare minimum, especially for a hotel of this price and reputation. I will never be staying here again.

title: Still the St Regis but not as crisp
text:
I’ve been coming to the St Regis 4-6 times a year for over 20 years and this was my first time back since the pandemic. I would say the experience and comfort are still the same but some of the magic is lacking. I noted an early check in in the app, but the room wasn’t ready upon arrival. Normally I get a free upgrade due to my high status and centurion membership, but it was “not available” even though all the big suites were available online and the hotel was noticeably empty. Ok fine whatever, I got a lower grade room that was ready right away bc I didn’t want to wait. 

The service was friendly but slow, the butlers didn’t have training in basic things like the room service menu or salon services which left me calling to figure things out on my own. Called for a butler one night to have my shirt pressed for an important event I was attending that evening. Didn’t come so I left it in the hook in the hall hoping they’d get the message. Was picked up but 90 mins later, still no shirt. I call to page the butler, no one comes. Had to call reception and them track the butler down, he finally came and apologized for the delay, it was apparent he was overworked and probably servicing multiple floors. Not excusable to be understaffed when paying $1800/night, the revenue from one room could pay the annual salary for a fleet of butlers, let alone just one serving the whole floor. 

Finally got dressed up and ready to go, I wanted to take a few pictures as this was the first formal event I’ve attended since before the pandemic, was promptly yelled at by a barrage of security (3 rude men) who swiftly started grilling me what I was doing, what room am I staying in, and that photography is strictly prohibiting and return to my room or leave. Really??? 

Suffice it to say I was 45 minutes late to my event mainly due to the hotel, but luckily I had such a good time this inconvenience was mostly forgotten. 

Some positive notes, the gym is recently redone and very nice, the King Cole bar is still a favorite watering hole, and the room service always arrived at the perfect temperature which is sometimes hard to do with eggs. 

All in all the St Regis still feels like my home in New York, however given the service issues experienced, I might change up my routine next time and stay somewhere else.

title: Great service; lousy infrastructure
text: I stay here several times a year.  Three of last four nights the in-room TV hasn’t worked.   Clearly systemic problem.  Not good for business travelers who need to check in on events at beginning g and ending of day.  Staff is great, but tech doesn’t work.

title: Exceptional service. Jessie in Astor Court is the best.
text:
Service. Service. Service. All staff were exceptional, polite and helpful. 

6 stars to Jessie for attentive, professional and fun service at Astor Court for breakfast each morning. She is such a giving person. Working hard to make sure every request was met while going out of her way to stay thank you to us for visiting.

title: Great stay
text:
Got upgrade to massive suite and it was a great stay. As an Ambassador elite, it was a lovely and fantastic short experience at this grand hotel. The standard room looks great btw so even without upgrade it still seems okay. 

Not familiar with NY hotel fee but it looks like the fee is acceptable with some of the usable credits.

title: Another wonderful stay at this beautiful hotel
text: I have been staying at the St. Regis New York for years and it never disappoints.  The rooms are spacious and beautifully furnished.  Beds are very comfortable and the bathrooms are terrific -- excellent water pressure in the shower, luxurious bathtub, nice amenities.  Every member of the staff went out of their way to make sure my stay was perfect!  Room service breakfast was delicious.  Housekeeping was impeccable as always.  Can't wait to go back!

title: St. Regis quality service
text: We stayed for a week at the St. Regis in NYC on points. We reserved 2 rooms and they were able to put our friends next to us (not always a sure thing). As Platinum Elite we  received a full American breakfast in the restaurant every morning which was a great way to start of a day of sight seeing. The staff was fantastic, especially the doormen who jumped to help us in and out of cars in the rain. We were at a level that included butler service,but we really didn't have need of it. The turn down service was nice, though.

title: New and Creative Methods to Nickel and Dime Customers
text:
I've left other reviews of this hotel and the Mandarin Oriental, my last review of the St. Regis NYC was 5 star.  This trip was just utterly annoying, marginal service at best, and every means necessary to separate the guest from his money.  It's pretty  pathetic.   
Believe what you're reading about this place-  the reviews I read about strange fees, new fees, hard to understand fees-  I saw countless of these reviews and yes it's all true.   
So I used points to book 2 separate rooms, mind you that's 170,000 points, I'm Titanium Elite.  But it's still 2 rooms, I could have booked separately, or under 1 reservation.  They tell me only 1 room gets the included breakfast.  So the room with 2 people, they both get the included "American breakfast."  I gave it to my 2 guests, since I'm just one.  When they go to breakfast, they had to literally push and pull to get this breakfast.. first it's just American breakfast, then there's a limit, then it wasn't included in both rooms (we know!)..    We also get $50 per person- which we PAID for already in destination charges-  this CANNOT be used at the bar, has to be restaurant/room service?  So couldn't I used the overall $150 for my breakfast, their's is included?   NO! evidently not.  Their $50 is only usable for the individual person?  So they got breakfast (but if you go over an amount, you CAN'T use the 50?.  I couldn't use their 50 toward my breakfast, the 50 only is for the person, per room?  So if they don't use it, we can't bundle it to my breakfast is included.   These guy will do literally anything at all, anything-  to make sure it's confusing, annoying, and in the end, they charged us all for breakfast, nothing got included, we lost the $50, and this involved about 20 minutes with the front desk people trying to understand it.  While up at the desk, we saw 3 other parties literally pulling their hair out, trying to understand about the breakfast, the $50, etc.   They have one company policy:  don't make it easy, don't give anything away, money is not interchangeable even between members of the SAME party, and utilize basically awful service.

Sorry:  if you want to be 5star, stop being so confusing, petty, and in love with overcharging and double charging and saying "nothing is included" to every question.  Try harder St Regis.  You'll lose loyal customers.

title: Nice butler and restaurant, that's about it
text:
I've paid a hefty 85k Marriott points and used a Suite Upgrade Award on this property. I can't comprehend why anyone would spend cash here, considering how awful the experience is. The property itself is okay, not quite my style, but I guess it may appeal to some. The butler service is a nice touch - our butler was great indeed. She has happily explained the service, delivered tea on a silver tray and picked up/returned laundry. The restaurant is rather small, but perfectly fine and the service impeccable - probably the best I've experienced in any hotel restaurant in the US.
That's about it for the positives. When you arrive at St. Regis your poor experience begins with checkin. The reception area is tiny and quickly becomes crowded. We've arrived at 3:15pm and have been told in a patronising tone that we're free to leave the luggage behind and go elsewhere, while they get the room ready, as the checkin time is 4pm. That's fair enough, you don't need to be patronising about it.
